>>"we'll so it in a small coalition" (there currently is none)
Wait until you find out Ukraine has been part of an EU battlegroup before this war even started.

https://blogs.fcdo.gov.uk/leighturner/2011/07/11/ukraine-joins-eu-battle-group/

I thought of this when on 1 July Ukraine joined the Greek-led Balkan EU Battle Group, sometimes also known as the HELBROC Battle Group (an acronym for HELlas, Bulgaria, Romania, Cyprus). An EU Battle Group is a stand-by military force designed to give member states the ability to provide rapid response elements in support of the Petersberg tasks (“military tasks of a humanitarian, peacekeeping and peacemaking nature”). This is the first time Ukraine has joined such a group and she will work alongside the other nations for a six-month period, contributing 10 staff officers, a company of Ukrainian marines with their armoured vehicles, and an IL-76 strategic lift aircraft.

This is good stuff and shows the ability of the Ukrainian armed forces to cooperate with those of EU member states to practical effect. It also reflects on support provided by the UK, including a month-long training package in Crimea designed to help Ukrainian troops work with those of other countries; and English-language and other professional training. The Ukrainian marines have a good reputation – the UK is grateful to them for having helped evacuate British nationals, alongside Ukrainians and other nationalities, from Tripoli in April. By working with other nations in the EU Battle Group, the Ukrainian armed forces boost the ability of all the countries involved to work together in the interests of peace, promoting people-people links and basic trust and understanding in a way which 20 years ago would have seemed almost inconceivable.

In my experience it's the person rather than the object that causes those issues. I think it's valid to see it as an outlet for an already lazy, unmotivated attitude, and it probably perpetuates that, but I can't say that anyone I've known to abuse it to that extent was already on their way to being a rocket surgeon before using, nor do I think it stopped them. The only thing I think it really does is making you "okay" with being complacent and bored, which has obvious dangers if you're already prone to lazing away the day. The rest is on the person; it can be enjoyed responsibly if you're responsible, or irresponsibly if you're not. So it's life-changing in that using it to cope with your circumstances or shortcomings doesn't motivate you to change your life.

>>56869667
In short, yes.
Even though they obviously fumbled the invasion and have burned a substantial share of their invasion force, they still have some serious capabilities that cannot be ignored.

The elephant in the room is their nuclear arsenal. As russian leadership is stuck in Cold War logic, paranoid and in parts bat shit insane, you have to account for that. Even though terminally online meme brains might laugh at this, it is a serious issue. Specifics of the risk model are obviously classified, but gambling millions of lives is something decision makers cannot just brush aside.

Then there is their strategic reserve fleet of vehicles. It’s massive. Look at tanks as an example. Even if we consider that only T80U/BV and T72B derivatives are either usable or can be upgraded to something with significant combat value, that’s a lot of tanks. I do not have the current military balance spreadsheet available, but we are still dealing with more hulls than they had in active service pre invasion just in reserve stocks. Then there are huge stocks of other vehicles, maybe some other anon could provide some insight in terms of numbers.

They also have a highly militarized population that lives in a totalitarian police state and is subject to propaganda for decades. You might argue that they hold little value, but an army still needs a lot of bodies and they have a large reserve of those.

We are not out of the woods yet and underestimating Russias ability to sustain conflict would be a mistake. That does not mean that we can’t defeat them. It just means that we will have to commit significant resources to do so while not making monkey man flip the board.

On the issue of the UK sending tanks: those tanks provide no actual combat value. It’s about boiling the frog. And about domestic issues that are not related to the war.
The question which tank model the west will send boils down to strategic questions that have little to do with the conflict in Ukraine.

The HIMARS system isn't long enough to utilize such a system. This is all just spitballing, so, bare with me: An ATACMS warhead weighs 213kg - 243kg, and has a range of 270km - 300km. It uses, roughly, a 9ft long, 2ft wide booster to achieve this. Now, take the 9ft booster and strap your 2000lb 10ft mine on the front, and you have a 20ft surface launched mine. Problem is, it will be sticking 6ft-7ft out of your HIMARS launcher, and have a range of 75km max. So, you're going to need to move to a Mk57 VLS or similar custom launch tube, as it won't fit in a Mk41 VLS. Now, if you're wanting more than 75km range, you're going to need to add another booster to that ATACMS, which is going to get you a 30ft long SL-mine that will need a custom launch tube. To me, it just doesn't make sense to spend that money when you have all these other options already in service - or that could be modified with minimal work.

posts.com:
I went in expecting a pure propaganda piece like Top Gun of the "Russia is invincible and honourable desu with sci-fi weapons, slava Z" but I was proven very wrong.

The film alternates frequently between cuts to different groups of Wagner and Ukrainian forces. Whilst it is mostly focused on the wagner forces, by actually having the plot follow Ukrainian groups at certain times it gives them a lot more character and depth. Whereas in movies like Blackhawk Down or other more modern US war movies every "bad guy" is a nameless jackie iraqi, in this film it felt like they gave a lot of respect to Ukrainian forces. They were not shown as just paper target retards.

The film in several scenes depicts Ukrainian soldiers as ferocious, vicious fighters, brave, cunning, calculating and dedicated. Of course this treatment is also the same for the depiction of Russian wagner forces too. The film also isn't above showing the grittier or less than honourable stuff. For example there is one scene where a wagner PMC is overrun by Ukr soldiers and hides under a dead Ukr to ambush one of the soldiers (then he is swiftly gunned down), both sides shoot at enemy wounded.

In terms of overly dramatic stuff, there are a few showcases from both the wagner and Ukr forces of soldiers being "fucked" e.g a tank is immobilised and makes a last stand, a guy is hit in an artery and rushes another guy with grenades in his hands ect. It does detract from the otherwise more grounded tone of the film but it is still cool.

The ending is very pyrrhic and is not shy about showing the cost of the war.

One of my favourite aspects was the creative cinematography of certain shots. I won't get too into it but it adds a lot of amazing effects to the pacing and spices up the energy of it all. [It can be hard to tell who is who in certain scenes but that does seem to be intentional as it is used as a minor plot point]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A video of Finnish volunteers fighting in Ukraine.
This is what your first combat mission would probably look like.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lWlk_OHJQ3Q

Really captures the SNAFU of the situation. Especially what the combat stress does to your thinking. You have weapon systems which you have not been trained to use. Any plan you had goes out of the window immediately. Your squadmate gets hit within first couple of minutes and your car gets destroyed.

Yeah... forget all those dreams about high-speed-low-drag operational operating.
Once your adrenaline and stress hormone levels peak, all sensible thinking goes out of the window. Even if you are decently military trained soldier, you suddenly can't think straight. You literally can't talk straight but rather communicate on a vocabulary level of Gorilla's "boots-and-banana". You can't even find your way out of farmstead courtyard. You try to blow up a hole into a corrigated steel fence. And most of your time you just end up wandering around trying to find some medivac for your downed pal (who, despite being hit in the sole of his feet, is certain he is going to die). And in the end, you didn't really achieve shit.

This is why previous combat experience is so important and why it makes such a difference. Why rookies get wasted so often. You have to be able to keep your head cool.
Adrenalin is a hell of a drug.

>>56841949
Spears only do shit if the infantry wielding them is braced in formation and takes the cavalry charge head on.
Getting spears into formation and bracing them takes up time, espeically if you use pikes instead. Cavalry however can maneuver quickly and flank a formation. Even if the cavalry doesn't get a charge in, it can force the enemy to maintain a position and constantly brace for charges while risking nothing.

At times cavalry can also charge spear formations head on. Attila supposedly did it many times. The most famous example are the Winged Hussars because their lances were simply longer than those of the enemy.

but they werent entirely making new types of armor, just more protective

Courtrai (1302) disagrees. It's actually an interesting case study of a charge, since it didn't turn out like most people think charges do. Some of the most high ranking men to take part in battle (who can be safely assumed were the richest, most motivated and well equipped of the lot) were named and reported to plunge deep into formation, only to be dragged off and killed. The Flemish had impressive amounts of cohesion that day, but charges usually never reached that stage in the first place. If nerves did not fail, then the charge was aborted, and we read constantly of multiple charges being made in a battle.

that's very interesting
most of my historical background is Eastern Europe military formations, which relied on cavalry much more than Western ones
the famous Winged Hussars (15th century onwards, beyond OP's range, I know) relied on incredibly well equipped troops with fanatical morale
once Poland has started to decline in wealth the formation became obsolete, it is a common myth that it was due to firearms - before the gatling it was too early to actually affect them
hussars had lanced longer than most contemporary pikemen, that's why they could destroy swedish and russian formations of the time, however one lance was an intricate construct of many different kinds of wood in order to make it light and actually usable in a fight, that drove the cost up once again
overall, heavy cavalry charges could've stayed feasible well into the 19th century but they became prohibitively expensive to fund

I guess they had it researched and practiced to a minute details, since they were professional soldiers with years of training and service in the same unit behind them. Unlike most volunteer and mercenary units, the banner (unit) was retained on pay between campaigns by its proprietor and titular commander and composed of the same men, usually between 18 and 30yo and unmarried, always from the leading noble families of the region, often related or known to each very well before entering the service, being educated in local colleges and courts and attending regional parliaments. The banner commanders and officers served for life, until disabled or infirm, since it was the most prestigious military post in Commonwealth`s army. So lots of time and incentivee to build a cohesive and well trained force.

Mercenaries were actually fairly reliable. The idea that they were duplicitous and acted in bad faith in battle comes from Machiavelli and he was full of it. Machiavelli came from the growing Italian bourgeoisie class, which resented and loathed the region's strongmen and princes, and their feudal armies.

Mercenary companies operated on a code of honor. These men were professional soldiers, first and foremost. Historical records of mercenaries betraying their employers or acting in bad faith are rare.

armored horses were a thing WAY before the 14th century.
>picrel from 4th century
There seems to me a few necessary factors for the local development or deployment of armored horses.
1: a strong and stable militaristic state.
2: a horse centric culture.
3: sufficient economic surplus to support the fancy and very expensive armor production for already expensive horses.
Thus when funds dry up or dynasties are in flux, horse armor recedes in the historical record.
The same reason M1 abrams aren't developed or produced in Chad, or Burkina Faso today.
Perhaps you meant plate steel barding, in which case disregard my rambling.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56860646
Jack of plates or coat of plates is the precursor to the brigandine. They resembled something more like a modern plate carrier but with iron or steel plates and would be worn over traditional gambison and mail armour to offer greater protection to vital organs. Brigandines were later in history and consisted of smaller and more articulated plates offering more flexibility and greater coverage. They would be go straight over an arming jack and would be considered a complete piece of armour and alternative to a full breast plate

You're right, I misread OP. Brigandine would not have been around in the late 1300s so you're looking at mail armour with possibly a breast plate or coat of plates. Sallet too would not have been around so you're looking at a bascinet as in OPs image.

Like I said in a previous post, brigandines were considered an essential part of the kit along with a breast plate in the 15th century. A knight was expected to bring both and it was largely down to preference what they wore. Don't forget at the time it was popular to decorate armour with paint or fabric so a lot of images may well have been brigandines or decorated plate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56866175
In this period, cavalry was distinguished by two very broad groups - men at arms and everything else. Men at arms were equipped to a certain minimum standard, but their defining feature would had been barding for the horse. Oddly the degree of horse protection seems not to have mattered as long as it existed and could even be cloth. "Everything else" would be your "light cavalry" and were known by various names: varlets, armati and other ambiguous and generalist terms that occasionally meant men at arms like esquire and armiger. Unfortunately these lesser cavalry were often not mentioned in records, but they seems to have typically existed in at least the same number as men at arms.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56870861
Yes, that is what the statute states. However, it is not a blanket ban on assembling semi automatic firearm, if you read the statute it states: "It shall be unlawful for any person to assemble from imported parts any semiautomatic rifle or any shotgun which is identical to any rifle or shotgun prohibited from importation under section 925(d)(3) of this chapter as not being particularly suitable for or readily adaptable to sporting purposes except that this subsection shall not apply to..."

The keyword here being "identical", which is why you add us made parts per 27 CFR 478.39, to maintain 922r compliance. This is why importers bring all AK's in as sporters, and add 922r compliance parts for distribution.

When it comes to the brace ban being retroactive, that's where it gets spicy. Theoretically, if it came in as a pistol and was Form 1'd and 922r compliant upon conversion, having never had a brace attached, there should be no legal issue. Having had a brace attached is where the issue comes into play if the gun were not 922r compliant. I still think it's foolhardy to panic at this point, as I'm sure a ton of clarification will be coming down.

>>56865188
Its the same in South Africa. Apartheid was predicated on cultural separation, on account of the fact that every time the two cultured shared a space it resulted in bloodshed. Elements of it were petty (known as Petty Apartheid) but they were largely removed by the mid-1970's. Blacks were also give quasi-autonomous "homelands" that generally reflected the core of their old tribal domains. But these were poorly administered and the South African government, for various reasons, never gave them the groundwork to flourish.

For the rank and file white South African, Apartheid was more about communism than anything. Its no coincidence that the Group Areas Act (formalization of Apartheid) and the Suppression of Communism Act passed side by side. If you ask former conscripts about their time in the army the answer depends generally on what they did. If they got sent to fight the war in Angola, generally they loved it and generally they were proud of what they did. If they got used internally to suppress black dissent they generally hated it and are not proud of their service. When Mandela was preparing for the elections, and for a long time after becoming President, he bent over backwards to console White fears about communism. He knew that the vast majority of Whites were more concerned with the communist and socialist insanity of post-colonial Africa than sitting next to a black person at work.

Its a tremendously complex issue that has been completely defaced by the hard left and right to push their various competing interests.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Fantastic, they had basically nothing and got some of the most impressive victories in history against better funded and better equipped rebels. They were a fantastic fighting force and their fire force strategy is pretty well regarded and well studied. Also one of the few African countries that actually tried to uplift its population, which is a rarity. Not too shabby, sadly it’s economy was built around exporting grain, and it was basically locked out of trade with most of the world except Israel and South Africa, who were also notably limited in trade. A lot of their issues came from the western powers, most notably Britain and America, completely embargoing them. The US still had active segregation going on during a good chunk of the bush war, so make of that what you will.
Regardless, the Rhodesian armed forces and especially the selous scouts were top of the line guys who did the impossible with whatever they could scrape together. I suggest reading up on their strategies and tactics, and how you can learn from their many victories and their ultimate loss

>>56856581
>I really hate flavor of the year bolt gun cartridges. 308, 300WM, and 223 cover everything you could ever need from a centerfire rifle cartridge and they won't die out in a few years like the latest and greatest new thing probably will.
I hate absolutest statements, and I say that as someone who only has 22, 9mm, and 308 (in new guns, not counting ancient stuff which I don't actively shoot often). I agree that the vast VAST majority do not have their skill remotely maxed out by those cartridges. I agree that the retards who constantly jump and shill fotm even to newbies while ignoring economics and such are jackasses. But
>you could ever need
There are in fact people who really do shoot ultra long range competitively. Who really have hit the limits of what those old cartridges can do. There is no doubt as a matter of fundamental physics that some of the new ones have much higher BCs and will carry more energy farther, flatter. We can manufacture stuff now with precision that we couldn't 50 or 75 or 100 years ago. People who know what they're doing can go with whatever they want. And most of them also reload, which negates a lot of the cost issues as well.

I also don't actually think 308/300/223 will be forever, because there is a slow accumulation of tech that I think will eventually mean a big switchover, and it might as well be to something with better BC while we're at it. Like, if it becomes compelling to move to polymer cased telescoped rounds ANYWAY because they're lighter, cheaper, more compact and more durable, well might as well also go to 7mm or whatever advanced computer modeling indicates is the best.

Not that this shit doesn't all get heavily over hyped to squeeze more money from the common man, but at the same time I'm glad the upper 1% of shooters keep probing the limits. I just wish manufacturers weren't such greedy fags about it.

This will depend upon whether your vision can be corrected, hence why vision requirements specify "correctable" or "corrected", I forgot which. NFOs are permitted to have slight vision problems that are corrected using either surgery or glasses. You will have to go through a lengthy medical waiver process if you get surgery. Hey Morautist can you help me out? I'm trying to decide on a Mora for outdoor tasks, mostly batoning wood and cutting off kindling.

>Companion Stainless
>Companion Heavy Duty

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56853888
>mostly batoning wood and cutting off kindling.
have you considered that these are tasks best suited to an axe?
https://morakniv.se/en/product/lightweight-axe-b/

Otherwise I prefer carbon steel to stainless. Unless you are using the knife in salt water it would be my recommendation to go with carbon steel.

Mora basic has a more secure grip with a bit of a guard molded in. Get it if you prefer this. The Mora companion has better rubberization and would be my pick in wet environments. Get it if you prefer this, or as an all around knife. The heavy duty does have a thicker blade, but I've watched people hammer a mora into a tree and jump on it without it breaking, so blade strength is not a genuine concern in my mind. It does however have a larger handle that may be more comfortable if you have large hands. Get it if you prefer this.

Carbon steel is very easy to care for, at least on the Mora. If you're really worried, cut up some onions or lemons before doing anything with the knife, then clean it off with water and dry after about a minute. This will help jumpstart the forming of a patina which will protect the blade.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56858256
Good knives. The steel they use is very middle of the road hardness. If you're a restaurant chef I would say that's a good thing. The really hard Japanese steels like vg10/vg max like my Shun work up really sharp and stay that way. Great for a really dedicated home cook. But they chip easy and they're not exactly stainless.
Globals, henckels etc. work up reasonably sharp and can tolerate a lot more abuse.
Cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56858756
The cheap ones are too soft. But the expensive ones are good. But at that price you could get something else.
>>56858832
Cont.
More important than the steel is your primary chopping style. Do you keep the tip of the blade on the cutting board and rock it up and down? You might like a wusthof or a gyuto styled knife.
Or do you lift the blade and push chop? You might prefer a French knife like a Lion Sabatier or something like a santoku or Chinese slicer like a CCK. Are your hands big small or average?
Are you really dedicated to blade maintenance and the craft and willing to get a carbon steel knife and earn a patina?
Carbons, irrespective of hardness will sharpen sharper and hold a blade longer than a stainless. But they require a lot of maintenance. I have a carbon Sabatier K olive handle and a CCK small slicer and I had to baby them for a long time. They both have deep brown patinas now that help protect the blade and prevent it from immediately rusting as long as I get to it in a reasonable amount of time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56862755
Hitting a moon with a kinetic impactor like that is going to end up with a pretty big chunk of said moon falling into the gravity well of the planet. Given Pandora orbits a gas giant, that means those nearly priceless materials become unsalvagable.
Then you have the trouble of navigating and recovering material from a fresh and relatively dense debris ring. It would take time for said ring to smooth out into something uniform that is made of mostly small bits like Jupiter or Saturn. Then you've made yourself the problem of having to prospect over a surface that is orders of madnitude larger than the moon to find what you're looking for, and hope that all those micrometeorites don't punch holes in your mining equipment while you're at it.
It's a bad idea.

The history of colonialism is pretty illustrative.

When the poorer countries didn't have access to modern western small arms, they just got streamrolled. But after WW2, when the USSR was suddenly a superpower, AKs and RPGs started to flood in. Combined with the new doctrine of Maoist guerilla warfare, and colonialism suddenly became untenably expensive.

I'd imagine it would be the same way in space. Unarmed peoples are only unarmed for so long.

Those bottles are usually filled with 50%alc vodka, though i fill them with 70% when i can, but that's hard to find here (bc)

>soak a sizeable piece of papertowel in vodka and wipe your face, hands and maby even your tosro and balls with it, takes the sweat off great, feel refreshed!

Ive never owned a woobie, couldn't say, and don't think one would fit in that bag. Rather dress in layers, wear enough clothes to survive an unexpected night out, though i admit having a sweater strung around your waist on a hot day isnt very fun.
Alternatively or in addition; Even in my smallish (20L)day pack survivalbag, that i occasionally bring, doesn't contain a jacket, but rather a full additional under-layer of clothing, and a heat-reflective poncho and tarp.

Steel is used where appropriate on Pandora but it's generally a bad idea to make vehicles and mechs out of them, because Pandora has lots of insanely strong magnetic fields. All the vehicles need to be made of ceramics or nonmagnetic, nonconducting metals.

At the heavier end, you've got Uncle Carl, the latest versions of which are (barely) light enough to be man-portable with a decent loadout. Carl also has a truly absurd variety of ammo types to play with.

Also, don't forget that most of the time, weapons like this are for emergencies, against pop-up threats when there isn't enough time to call for air or fire support. That's especially true today, now that PGK/PGMM can offer serious firepower with a <10m CEP. So, the requirements are different than what you'd expect for such a weapon.

>any game with a significant amount of guns of the same type (ie assault rifles) or accessories will blow the differences between them way out of proportion to the point where players can notice the difference in performance just by using them rather than needing measurement equipment (such as paper targets and a ruler for measuring groups, or a shot timer to measure the hundredths of a second you're shaving off the per shot during drills)
>FPSes in general have tons of balancing concerns that go into the design process for close quarters parts of maps to keep them actually enjoyable and balanced rather than just being a slog that mostly comes down to luck

Its a game where you can apply a tourniquet to your chest.

The armor is all 100% coverage of given body parts.
The helmets actually stop rifle rounds
Face shields can block rifle rounds even.
The health system is straight up magical, just they called their magic potions things like "surgery kit" so it looks realistic.
The recoil is atrocious, and no, they will never make it decent.
In sum, it is an MMORPG with gear and character leveling, and most of the balance is for the sake of that system, not realism or playability. There's lots of nonsense, like turning an ir gun laser on (without nods) will give you better hip fire...
A bunch of attachments are not going to take a spraycan Ak74U and turn it into a recoilless laser. The weapon modding is all extremely overwrought to tie into the RPG system.
Yes, armor piercing ammo exists IRL and there are tiers of armors and ammos. I lack the statistical background to say how accurate the game is, just I'll note that again all of this is part of their RPG plan and is likely only going to dimly reflect reality.

Its a fun game, but it only had the veneer of realism. While most games alter that veneer for the sake of fun, tarkov alters it for the sake of RPG mechanics and grind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Tarkov is held back by tech and engine. The gameplay itself is fun once you "get" it and learn to play your own way.
It's still a game, not a mil sim. The systems in play do a decent job of feeling like representations of real life considerations, but they are still structured on gameplay, rather then IRL. Exaggerations and inaccuracies are all over.

This latest wipe has brought with it terrible audio and questionable performance(both network and frames) on the new map Streets of Tarkov. This has led to a very justified backlash.
Streets itself is a great map if you can get past performance issues. When you start learning the key areas and locations it can lead to some great fights and action when it's running right, it's also absolutely swimming in loot. That is all based on the big "if you can run it... and hope to fuck you don't walk into a network bubble".
One lesser known secret is that night time streets is actually completely playable and runs better then day. Devs made good use of dynamic light sources and you can even shoot out street lights and create concealment.

>>56870978
Have EOD, can confirm its P2W as fuck. If Tarkov was the game it should be, the argument that EOD is the full edition and worth the price would probably be valid, but read the thread of course its not. Having EOD compared to standard version saves probably well over 100 in game hours, all of which are grinding, mind you. Beyond that, the full stash isn't even shit, containers are where its at, the best ones which give you like a 6:1 to 10:1 space expansion being like 8-15 million throughout the wipe.

Here's a fun tip: If you're trying to make money, having gear is fucking retarded!

Here's how I averaged 500k per 10 minute raid.
>have EOD
>have Shoreline resort full key case and injector case
>load in with USP w/ .45 AP and Berkut (25k)
>sprint to resort in a completely straight line
>use USP to kill any scavs in the way
>run to room 301E or 219W depending on what side you're on
>you now most likely have exceeded the cost of your kit tenfold by shit in your secure
>if you hear no one coming, which you most likely will before they're on you, keep looting
>if you get really lucky and full loot before anyone shows, you're talking well over a million for a near zero investment
>if you hear anyone coming, pop propital, jump out window, beeline extract
>this entire process takes about 10 minutes and with the skills system you get faster every single time at an extremely high rate

Mind you, this is two wipes out of date so things like propital negating damage is gone and I have no idea if Shoreline still has that insane of loot, but it made the game a joke. If I had two hours to kill I could make 4 million plus loose meta kit and then run slicks (which I'd accumulated by camping the trader restock all day like a no life) half a dozen raids in a row, dying, not caring at all.

Oh also if you want a hot take on moderation in that game, my name was NIGGERS and my friends names were similar, never got banned, level 50+ two wipes in a row.

>>56866846
>>56866758
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s9RPHmd9k_U
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ikEI7b-_CGY
Krylon fusion is known to be extremely hard to remove from guns.
It'll wear through on points that stick out if you keep the gun in a holster, but otherwise holds up very well.
Let it fully cure before fucking with it.
Also know that you might fuck up tolerances depending on where you spray it (places like mag well might get tacky and require some sanding)

posts.name: Burt
posts.com:
>>56866758
You certainly can dye polymer (and resin), it is always additive however. So you cannot make it lighter but can always add colors (add blue to yellow to get dark green for example), eventually ending in black. Pic related PMags in the lower right started as "sand" colored and after an hour in cocoa dye are now that color. It can't penetrate all the way through solid polymer though, only a little ways into the surface, so if you get a deep enough ding or gouge the original color will show through. These dyed PMags for example have sand colored lines where the mag catch has scraped them.

Like anon said, Omaha guns are cerakoted though, I don't think you can dye cerakote.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56860214
I think British thought at the time was having the guns spread out reduced the risk of cook offs and reduced the amount of disabled guns taken out when hit.

IE with 3 turrets if 1 gets hit you lose 1/3rd of your fire power while with 4 turrets if 1 gets hit you only lose 1/4th your fire power and depending if you are retreating or not you can still maintain shots on the enemy.

(Also tech at the time as other 3 gun turrets had to have all 3 barrel elevated at the same time)

could be wrong though.

Then Ferrari contacted all of their 550 buyers and flew them to Italy for a luncheon to ask them what they wanted in the next iteration. Most anarchist armies don't work, but the Black Army enjoyed unique success among anarchists' (for a while anyway) precisely because Makhno wasn't retarded and knew he had to utilise basic concepts like a command structure. The biggest problems with anarchist armies tend to be that they utterly reject shit that is vital for a modern army to work properly. The anarchists of the Spanish Civil War were a perfect example of this, they would show up to their designated barricade, fire off a couple our rounds into the air, then go home, considering their daily duty to the republic complete. They would also refuse to do certain assaults or commands because they didn't feel like doing it at that time, to the point where their commanders had to come to the frontlines and beg them to follow orders.
The Black Army did not suffer these problems as much because Makhno was kind of a mythical/larger-than-life figure to his men. Because of his position at the top of the Black Army, they implicitly trusted that Bat'ko would lead them to victory, so were more than happy to follow orders.
This didn't gel well with some members of the Free Territory, because as much as they also respected him, they thought he was putting fundamentally Authoritarian principles into the Free Territory, but Makhno was careful to keep the military power of the Black Army firmly separate from the civilian and communal organisation of the Free Territory. This did also result in certain drawbacks to the Black Army, such being one of the few Russian Civil War armies that didn't use conscription, meaning the BA had way less men than basically every other army, but their morale was way higher than pretty much any other army in the civil war.

Life is hard and full of inconveniences, putting your recruits through a mandatory process that changes them as individuals is important in being able to work better as a team. There is a difference between pure abuse, and just tough love. As a child might be parented, so do troops, this is for their own good. >>56858025
So, there seems to be some misconception out there as to what the trials actually were. A lot of people seem to think that the trials were the selection part of the whole procurement contract, but thats not correct.
The trials were a way for NDMA to test the vehicles in different winter conditions, running them through different firing tests, driving tests, etc etc.
Basically the goal was to a) get NDMA familiar with the performance of both contenders and b) get the contenders to understand why NDMA requirements were the way they were. This was then used in towards the technical negotiations before summer 2022 and the final negotiations before Christmas 2022.

But in short, while the actual X,Y,Z result of each test of the trials are secret, both contenders performed well enough to not be dropped. Back when NDMA did the artillery trials they dropped the first 2 contenders not long afterwards, but that was more from a combination of requirement fulfillment AND lessons learned during the trials than the trials themselves.

So the tank trials went pretty much as expected regarding the A7 with no major discoveries etc, but it was more important for HRC to show that "yes, our tank can actually work in winter conditions", which it could.
And NDMA got the insight into both vehicles and the ability to tweak/adjust the requirements where needed.

posts.com: Story tiem. How did Norway choose Leopards the first time? Reminded that before the Soviet Union ended, there were dearmament treaties between them an NATO to get the cold war out of what was then considered a rough time (hah!) and both sides agreed to cut down the number of tanks, among other times. At that time Europe was full of Leos and so a lot of them were lined up for scrapping because who could possibly want them... At that time, the Norwegian tank fleet was not far from being an actual museum with mostly M48s at hand. When the scrapping was announced the Norwegian government saw an opportunity. The treaty meant Norway could not add one tank to the roster - but they could chop up the old ones. So out went the 48s and in went about a 170 Leo 1s from the Dutch Army, for literally scrap price, quadrupling Norwegian Army combat strength and giving the russians and the lefties a heart attack from sheer anger. And that's how come Norway has been Leo country for four decades. It was a scrap yard bargain.

You are combining Leo 1 and 2 here a bit.
During the 70´s we purchased around 78 Leo 1´s, as well as having a mix of other shit (M48´s, NM116 and whatnot). In the 19080´s we did an upgrade program for the M48 into the M48A5 + buying some more vehicles, as well as upgrading the Leo up to 1A5NO version.
Then during the late 80´s we had the CFE agreements that basically said we could have 170 tanks. That led to the scrapping of all M48´s, M24´s, NM116 etc in favor of buying 92 additional Leo 1A5´s from Germany for cheap, and upgrading these. That left us with 170 Leo´s in compliance with the CFE treaty.
In 2002-2003 we purchased 52 old Leo 2A4´s from the Dutch Army and retired the last Leo 1´s around 2010 i think

>>56861632
Well it kinda depends on how you look at it. Every wargame or exercise we've done have shown that well-placed armour, ie an MBT or an IFV, can wreck havoc along chokepoints when placed in defensive roles. This is especially relevant for defence down the main northern MSR's which is dominated by valleys, narrow roads etc.
This ofc relies on area control against flanking movements such as light infantry and airborne etc, which is reflected in Norwegian armored battalions being that in name only, and actually closer to mechanized battalions with a 3-1 split between IFV and MBT squadrons.
As for the Finnmark plateau, you actually have quite a bit of maneuver freedom and nice, long areas of fire. Once the frost sets in proper, you can achive quite a lot of maneuver freedom as well.
Ofc there you open yourself up quite a lot to long-range ATGM-fire, which is one of the reasons why APS is presented on both the A7 and K2.

>Chillin' in the woods with some AT weapons is the way to go
Funny you should mention that, because that exact line of though is why the CV90 is the way it is, ie without a mounted ATGM capability like the Bradley has (bar the BILL demo and the new dutch ones). The CV design was focused towards combat against Soviet forces in marshy and wooden areas of northern Sweden, where movement would be restricted and visibility limited. The Cv90 was to engage channelized armor from the flank with the 40mm, while heavier AT was to be provided by dismounted infantry using ERYX or similar.
Turns out that this is pretty transferable to both Norwegian and Finnish terrain as well, although Norway has replaced the ERYX with the Javelin in recent years.

>Norway wants Panthers
Lol. Lmao

posts.com:
The K2 is a more modern tank.
They managed to fit a state of the art MBT into a hull the size of a Russian T model tank.
You get a tank that's on eye height with the M1 and Leopard 2 while offering minor advantages.

The Leopard 2 is known in and out by the Norwegians and Germans, so there won't be any bad surprises in terms of technical failure here. The S-Koreans had issues with their domestic transmission and engine and just bought German replacements as a stopgap measure.
Especially the engine development was really fucky but their product seems to do fine in Norway now.
Like any system, the K2 will have teething issues while the long served Leopard 2 won't.

It will take time until Poland has it's factory up and running, so the Leo 2 also has the edge from a logistical viewpoint too.
Then there is the price, the K2 will cost a fortune, which isn't really an issue for a small and rich nation like Norway.

My guess is that the Norwegians will choose the K2.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Norwegian here. The Norwegian military and to an extent the politicians have bought into the idea of being a "mini-USA", getting very high tech stuff like F-35, subs and new tanks. The problem is due to Norway being relatively small, we get few of them which means we have little operational mobility/loss capacity. Almost all the planes will be located in 1-2 bases and our navy is down to being just few ships, with half of these expensive toys being on maintenance.

This has been at the cost of other things, where the traditional infantry soldier has been neglected with so few people having served in the military nowadays. We should have gone the Finnish way, having all serve in the military and focus on weapons that give more bang for your buck, especially with the terrain we have here (i.e. Javelins, NLAWs, Stingers, NASAMS, Skjold missile boats, drones etc.). You wont see any armored pushes in the mountain ranges in Norway and it makes sense given the knowledge from Ukraine. The Chief of Staff suggestion to scrap the tanks makes sense, the problem is that the money saved probably would just go to some officers pushing papers or foreign aid in Africa.

>>56856232
I was in a multiplayer game with some guys from /vst/, and I was playing as Russia with the second highest score out of everyone. The one with the highest score was Japan, who was to my West, and to my South was Persia and Morocco, who were far behind Japan and myself but who had formed some kind of partnership. Japan invaded and took two of my coastal cities because I had neglected my navy, but I counterattacked by sending cavalry behind his lines and pillaging all his luxury resources so he was forced to return the cities or face total collapse from the unhappiness penalty. Morocco also attacked but didn't really do anything other than loot a trade route. I had lost a good chunk of my army during this war, but I decided to focus on rebuilding my cities instead of my army because I thought Japan had learned his lesson and wouldn't attack for a while.

Then Persia and Morocco invaded, with Persia sneaking an army right up to my borders by assembling it in a city state before attacking. I was caught completely off guard, and thought I was about to lose the game completely, but I quickly placed down a citadel in a mountain pass chokepoint between my southernmost city, the enemy city-state, Persia, and the rest of my territory, and started pumping out cossacks which I had just unlocked. Persia couldn't take the citadel and I managed to force them back into the sea, while Morocco couldn't take my southern city because the terrain was too difficult. I then decided fuck it, no more mr nice guy, and rushed artillery to kill everyone around me. Then everyone dropped out due to technical difficulties but by that point I had basically won the game. The most fun I've ever had.

Dsa type 3 are the most common since you can buy one right now, but I’ve found their machining to be a bit finnicky and picky with barrels. >unlined chromoly barrel
Chrome Molly Venedium barrels are lined though. When strictly speaking about barrels;
Phosphate < Nitride < CMV = Stainless Steel < Chrome Lined
That's still pretty fucking good. Most if not all the $1000+ rifles use CMV. Nitride treated barrels have been mostly left in the dust since CMV doesn't cost that much more and easier to do. You don't even see phosphate barrels anymore unless you go with Anderson or Palmetto, some bottom of the barrel manufacturer.

Was the M14 ever chrome lined? Genuinely asking, I'm not a historian.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56862525
This is all in my personal experience, others may chime in which is fine. I'm by no means an authority at all, this is my first/only battle rifle so far.
I'm at about 650-700 rounds through it, doing slow fire, a bit of magdumping at indoor ranges when no one else is around, off hand, strong hand, in different positions and from behind barricades/walls. I really like it so far, and it is by far my favorite bullpup that I own. (I have an x95 and sbr ps90, but have also shot most of the others)
For me:
Pros
>shoot big boolet
>gas adjustment is nice for tuning for different loads so your shooting experience between the various bullet weights is about the same (keltec has a video explaining how to adjust the gas, make sure you watch it, very very helpful)
>Size/OAL is really nice, and the ergonomics are fine. This isn't a 1R1 larperator gun so don't treat it like one, although I do like to challenge myself on the reload times when I go out.
>Accuracy is fine. It's not sub moa with anything I've shot through it but I can still plink away with ease at 500yd +

Cons
>Bit hefty but what battle rifle other than stuff like the SFAR isnt?
>Definitely a bit of a break in period involved, just stay on top of the gas setting and you'll be okay. I hit a point after 150-200 rounds where I was suddenly having FTFs and it was fixed by going through the gas adjustment procedure again.
>FAL mags. Yeah they're sovlful but goddamn are they pricey and hard to find unless you're willing to settle for thermolds.

I want to try steel ammo and a bunch of other shit but its hard when I work 60-70hr weeks. In due time, I suppose. I love my RFB.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: There will be lots of stupid replies to this, but the real answer, at least in the short term, is a highly distributed constellation of communications and reconnaissance satellites.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In the more medium to long term, it will put infrastructure into orbit to provide space dominance with it's unbeatable economy, IE fueling depots.

In space warfare you are highly limited in maneuver by reaction mass; fuel is vital.
Think of how in the early days of steamships, coal availability decided your operational abilities.
A fleet that went outside of the range of it's coaling stations and was forced to pitch sails was tactically and strategically immobile.
So these coaling stations decided the reach and influence of the naval empires.

In space fuel is even more vital, and starship, if it can achieve the kind of flight rate it aims for, will provide the ability to supply vital depots, around earth and lunar space, and potentially beyond.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56844850
It's 301, but yeah it seems you're right. I was misled by some talking point where they were discussing using inconel a few years back nevermind.
Either way starship needs to be able to survive reentry temperature and also not crack under the cryogenic fuel stored inside.

The only other contenders for it is similar variants of steel and nickel alloys.
A high numbered aluminium alloy is a possible choice but it is likely at risk of fatigue and cracking. Titanium maybe but idk, it is very expensive and has its own problems.

Basically, it seems barebones 301 is not only cheap, but is actually one of the better choices, and also the way it's shaped in the inside (using crisscross sections on the inside) it's actually quite a complex design for steel.

Turns out the engine bell of the raptor is sandwiched milled copper mated with an outer iconel jacket, so maybe that's what I got it confused with.

the reason everyone is calling you an idiot is not because you're an idiot, it is because you're unaware that the space shuttle tile system is very different in design from starship's and therefore starship's heatshield will not share the same fundamental flaws
>starship's mostly cylindrical hull shape makes commonality between tyles much easier whereas the space shuttle had most of it's tiles in a specific unique shape that wouldn't fit elsewhere.

>starship's tiles are not sitting next to a massive foam insulated hydrogen tank reducing danger of foam strikes to zero
>most tiles being hexagon shaped means that in the event of tiles being broken on orbit the prospect of people going out and affixing new ones is not really that radical at all.
>it's still in question if the heat shield would even need to be perfectly vaccuum sealed because the stainless steel hull actually has a pretty damn high melting or buckling temperature compared to fucking aluminium
>reflectivity of the hull is also the reason why only one side needs shielding whereas even the topside of the shuttle needed at least thermal blanketing.
>heat shield tile tech has not stood still since the space shuttle, newer tiles are less brittle and even more effective at taking heat loads, spacex has their own propriatary recipe.

>>56845545
>>56845561
>First it won't happen below 600km or so
You probably googled that and misunderstand what expert said.
Orbit are VERY short at lower altitude, decades of debris shredding everything that cross them and throwing some debris on higher orbit is enough to wipe out every sat you had there.
Debris of slightly different velocity, mass, shape will gradually spread over the entire orbit even before they hit something else.

You could very well be shredded by debris too numerous to track on the way up.
Needing to launch your rocket from say, the North/South pole on a very inefficient trajectory already justify the danger of the Kessler effect.
Since a complete satellite constellation also ask for satellites in polar orbit it will even be dangerous there.

Kessler Syndrome never locks access to space for any serious length of time. The lower orbits clear within a few years. From there you can send up dedicated cleaning craft (lasers to destroy debris or crafts to capture debris) into low orbits and work your way up into the higher orbits. Also remember that the volume of higher orbits is exponentially higher than that of lower orbits, meaning that Kessler Syndrome would already be much less dangerous simply due to all the debris being spread over a much larger space.

>>56867586
They've already gotten a 21 day turnaround time for a Falcon 9 booster.
However, let's just use a quite conservative pace for SpaceX in regards to Starship operation. With all of their production they are able to built one stack per month. Each stack can only fly once per month. After one month they have built and flown one Starship, capable of launching 100 tons to low Earth orbit. After two months they have built two Starships. The first has flown a second time and the new one has flown for its first time. They have a total 300 potential tons of mass to LEO so far. After three months they have built and flown a third one, and the other two have flown once again. Total potential mass to LEO thus far of 600 tons. At four months this is 1000 tons. At five months this is 1500 tons. At six months this is 2100 tons. After one year in which they build one stack per month and each stack flies once per month they have a total annual mass to LEO of 7800 tons. In their second year they have a total annual mass to orbit of 22,200 tons. Year three is 36,600 tons. Year four is 51,000 tons. Year five is 65,400 tons. After five years their total lifetime mass to LEO is 183,000 tons. After ten years the total lifetime mass to LEO of Starship is 726,000 tons.
I also did some more number crunching for a scenario in which SpaceX still builds one Starship per month but is able to launch each one once per week. The annual total for each year is 32,500 tons year one, 100,100 tons year two, 159,900 tons year three, 235,300 tons year four, 287,300 tons year five, 370,500 tons year six, 414,700 tons year seven, 505,700 tons year eight, 542,100 tons year nine, and 640,900 tons year ten. The lifetime total mass to LEO over those ten years is 3,367,000 tons.

>>56870638
You have no idea how space works. Reentry is on a global scale- retrorockets firing thousands of miles from where the plane will fight or land. During their descent, the planes will make huge S-turns spanning continents. Going thousands of miles an hour, a change on when to turn (and the tightness of the turn, say a slight change like a 2g to 3g turn) could change the expected location of the plane by thousands of miles.
Sustaining thousands of men in space is actually not that hard with starship. A regular cadence of starships would bring up fresh men, materiel, and consumables. The return trip would take back men at the end of their tour, broken equipment, etc. if a starship holds 100 tonnes, that’s a LOT of room for men. 100 tonnes is the total mass- a fully loaded 737 max (with 200 passengers) weighs less than that. So it would be possible to take several hundred men up at once in the people-mover configuration.

Cute anime, BTW. Nothing special, just slow, schoolgirl slice-of-life stuff. Very kid-safe, topical to our modern, changing world. >>56792002
>>56792014
Thanks. I know what it's like to put your creative work out for others to trash.

First, instant impression: picrel. Cool vibe. I got some nice visuals out of it, and (quick, cold read) it's a reasonably self-contained scene. Don't need background or context, so good stand-alone effort that doesn't require extra explanation.

Without getting too into the weeds, some phrasing is kludgy, some of the vocabulary doesn't fit all that smoothly, a couple of instances of over-repetition too close to each other.

> "as the feline construct"
> "with natural feline grace"
For example. Having to repeat "the Stone Jaguar" several times gets redundant, it's a bit awkward. "Sto-Jag" is an OK attempt at introducing a slang reference, but try to come up with 1 or 2 alternates so none appear within about a page of each other.

Using adjectives & such to get good visual communication going is a Good Thing, but some of the word choice isn't perfect, and there's a couple spots where extra adjectives could be cut for better flow in the reading.

> "blasting out the windows from the inside with fire and human viscera shrapnel"
Try slightly more economical for the same (or better) impact:
> "blasting out the windows from inside with fire and human shrapnel"
or
> "and human viscera"
or
> "with fire, shrapnel, and human viscera blasting out windows from within."

I'd rate a solid beta release draft, but it needs a paragraph-by-paragraph proofread by an editor to tweak it up a notch or two. A fair bit is too static for an active battle scene. The overall impact of the words needs to be more dynamic, less passive, a bit staccato & abrupt to immerse the reader in the chaos of a firefight.

> "He brought crosshairs to bear on his closest target, squeezing the trigger for a single, smokeless round of .308 and already seeking the next as the next round chambered. He didn't notice if the first stumbled from a hit or not, already firing at a second diving for cover."

Etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56792542
> "He brought crosshairs to bear on his closest target, squeezing the trigger for a single, smokeless round of .308 and already seeking the next as the next round chambered. He didn't notice if the first stumbled from a hit or not, already firing at a second diving for cover."
Damn. Still didn't nail it like I wanted. Maybe:

> "He quickly slid his crosshairs to the closest target, squeezing the trigger for a single, smokeless round of .308, already seeking the next as another round finished chambering. He didn't notice if the first man stumbled from a hit or not, already firing at a second diving for cover."

Just an example of editing & re-editing. Always keep your old edits, don't delete. Sometimes you want to go back to them if they don't work, or another edit nearby works better with the original. Or, the first drafts don't work on this page, but fit well in another scene a chapter away.

And, it's an artform to recognize when you're headed down a rabbit hole and Just. Stop. And move on to something else. Come back later and see if you're done already.

posts.com:
>>56805812
A Centaur would weigh significantly less than a mounted knight, and weight does actually make a significant difference on a charge. If a horse is injured, an armored knight can often fight as a foot soldier to good effect. Further, a centaur with a rider would be far more protected than a centaur without one, and far more dangerous in terms of being able to attack multiple targets at once or the same target from multiple angles.
Ultimately, a Centaur bearing a rider would defeat a centaur without one 99% of the time, and cavalry is all about force concentration.

I have a Warhammer 40k inspired Trump fanfic. It is about the near future, end of the century. The American Imperium is fighting against the hordes of GH. The reign of Emperor Barron Trump has been exceptional, but Barron is now over 100 years old and failing. There is a plot afoot to sit a Kushnerite hier on the Liberty throne and destroy the Imperium from within.

This is not a racist work and I do not condone racism! Actually, one the main characters is a Black shock trooper working for GH names L'D'Qu'arius Holmes. He is a fierce fighter and enemy of the Imperium, but comes to learn that his masters are using him and his people. There is a dramatic confrontation where the MC is captured and looks done for, but then L'D'QU'ARIUS turns on the feared Ashkenazim Warfiend Schmolo Sheckelocov, bellowing "yo name was on the slave ships," an emotional peak in his transformation.

Anyhow, here is an excerpt:

--
Trump Greogry flexed his corded muscles. Muscles honed from a lifetime of fighting. Though he had been born after the 2nd American Civil War, he had fought hard for the Imperium in both Asia and Mexico.

Growing up in a time of cataclysmic struggle, a clash of civilizations the likes of which the world had never seen before, had sharpened him. The generation before him had grown up soft, sipping soi lattes and playing vidya. They would be children until the age of twenty-six. Unable to fight, unable to care for themselves, they would consume far more than create.

This culture of moral degeneracy had led to physical degeneracy. Most couldn't pass the modern basic Trump Imperium fitness standards for fourteen year olds: a one plate (135lbs) standing military press, a two plate (225lbs) bench press, a three plate (315lbs) squat, and a four plate (405lbs) dead lift, all for five repetitions. Trump Gregory had reached these standards a week before turning 13, but of course, he grew up in a very different world.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56809853
He had fought hard for 10 years in Mexico. The Imperium had pushed as far south as the Panama Canal- and then disaster had struck.

A whole cadre of High Ashkenazim Warfiends, some 7,000, augmented by cybernetics and the Kabbalahic Probabilistic Trance, had landed, backed up by 10,000 elite Jews to lead the armies. Under the coordination of the latter, were 150,000 Communist and Antifa special forces, traitorous Whites with black hearts.

Then there was what soldiers like Gregory had called "The Unbreakable Wave." The breeding pits of Africa had gone silent after the carpet bombing campaigns of 2056 laid waste to the continent. Tungsten rods from space, hydrogen bombs, small meteorites pulled out of nearby space, and antimatter cluster bombs had racked the continent. It was a last desperate move to save Europe from being overwhelmed. And for awhile, it seemed to work.

What the Imperium did not know then is that the Jews had burrowed deep, deep underground. Beneath the Earth, unscathed by the Trumpian bombardment, whole pit cities filled with roided up Blacks, breeding constantly to the sound of trap music, and trained to a furious edge in combat remained. What these new soldiers lacked in tactics or ability to execute strategy, they made up for in sheer numbers and brutality.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56809879
And so Operation Flesh Golem had begun. Wave after black wave crashing against the Legions of the Imperium. The wave broke around the brave Legions, iron in their resolve, but flooded around them, ever forward, swamping them. The Unbreakable Wave. And striding above the Wave, the Ashkenazim Warfiends, hanging in thin air above the crowds, immune to rockets and jets, protected by Kabbalahic plasma shields, speaking unspeakable sorceries and firing down fusion beams to break holes in the Imperium lines for the Black hordes. It took over a decade, but the Legions were pushed back. Now, only the Great Trump Wall held back the Wave, mighty in solid gold splendor.

But today, Trump Gregory was dealing with politics. Some in the Texas border states questioned to loyalty of those few Black Legionairres, the ones who had been granted the legal status of Basedblackmen.
...Excerpt 2

Legate Trump Gregory lay prone, silent in the early dawn light of Mexico, a gray rock amongst the dry brown grass for the camouflage of his armor. The surrounding chaparral was washed to a uniform red brown by the sun slowly cresting the hill ahead of him to the east.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56809887
To be a soldier of the Imperium and on this side of The Great Trump Wall was dangerous enough. To be there alone, in daylight? This was a role reserved for elite legates like Gregory himself.

Silently, Trump Gregory moved his monocular back to his main quarry, the special forces soldiers of the XIth Border Legion's raiders, the Claws of Trump. Only half the unit was out this morning, fifteen men total. The were on a ridge to Trump Gregory's east, using the backlighting of the sun to obscure themselves; he had to use multiple filters on his monocular to see them clearly. They moved with slow and grim intent despite the great weight of their heavy arms and armor.

Below they spied their own prey. A beat up collection of four vehicles, two former flat bed trucks and two former buses, all remodeled into junk heaps. Armor playing had been haphazardly welded onto the sides, and barbed wire had been strung up around the beds of the large trucks. Mexican engineering no doubt.

The bed of the trucks, open to the air, showed what dread purpose the vehicles now served. They were filled with young girls, 12-18, young maidens of the Trump Imperium taken as slaves in border raids. The girls would fetch a good price as slaves south of the Wall. In remote areas, cross Wall attacks on settlements were a common threat, and the taking of young maids as chattel was a fate worse than death.

Surrounding the vehicles were about twenty tall, heavily armed black men. From the heavy plate armor they wore, and tribal face tattoos they had, Gregory knew these were no normal slave raiders. Each man stood at least six and a half feet tall, some more than seven. Their armor had custom cod pieces, and where their thighs met extended a massive Kevlar shaft of phallus armor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56809906
He used his monocular to measure the size of the phallus armor on several. Not a one less than 10 inches... "Bix Nubians!" Gregor thought. But why? Why would these elite forces be deployed for a slave raid? Were these girls more than the usual spoils of a raid? Were they choice maidens bound for the elite of the forces of Globalhomo?

Gregory looked back at the Claws of Trump, slowly moving closer to the vehicles. His mission was to remain hidden at all costs, to watch the men fight. He was to vet their effectiveness. If they preformed well, they would be used for more dangerous and important missions in the future. Though the threat the elite Bix Nubians posed was great, Gregory still thought the Claws were up to the task. They were not significantly out numbered and they had the element of surprise. This would be a good proving ground for them.

He panned back to the slave caravan and extended his sound measurement cone towards what appeared to be the lead Bix Nubian. He appeared to be directing the others, and was now in an argument with a huge seven foot tall monster in tactical plate mail, holding a large .80 calibur "gat" in one hand and a 40 ounce bottle of malt liquor in the other. He spoke forcefully.

"I'm just sayin motha fucka, they don't be needing all dese chicken head snow bunnies, we can try at least some out. Dey won't know tha difference."

The leader turned to the large one. "Nah dawg. You heard what L'T'Marqus be sayin. Dese girls is for that rabbi dude, don't be trippin dawg, we'll be gettin some when we get back."

Another, smaller, light skinned with intelligent eyes interjected from the side. "Yeah, but why we always be listening to them rabbis dawg. We the ones fighting. I know we be working for King Nigronius, but I be hearing people say all sorts of stuff, like he ain't even known about before he became king, like he ain't even black, like he be some sort of Jew in that blackfac-"

"Yo! Yo! Yo! You shut up mouth dawg. You fuckin trippin!? You sayin shit like dat be gettin us all killed," the large one bellowed. "I ain't trying to front on the King, I just be sayin they ain't gone know if we be trying a few out here. Ain't no cherry to be breakin if we do it in da booty."

Trump Gregory had heard enough, his stomach lurched at the thought of how many slave girls had been taken this way. He panned over to an open truck. It was strange the way the caravan had stopped here. Too close to the Wall to be safe, needlessly risky, even for confident Bix Nubians. But this worked to the Claws' advantage, they were closing ground even now.

The young girls looked cold and terrified. They huddled together, speaking in soft whispers he couldn't pick up. Soon they would be rescued.

But one girl caught his eye. She looked old for the group, maybe nineteen or twenty. She did not look scared and did not talk with the others. She stood imperious, proud. The others stayed apart from her, as if they feared her.

He zoomed in on her form. Something about he sent danger alarms running through his brain. Suddenly, she looked up at him, as staring directly at him through the monocular, though there was no way she could have seen him. The look was hard, it seemed to recognize the ambush coming, and yet it did not betray fear.

Suddenly a jolt of fear hit him. He panned down her body to her high, supple, large rounded breasts. "Those- those are Khazar milkers!" he almost yelled.

He wasn't supposed to let the Claws know he was there, not under any circumstances, but he now knew that this entire convoy must be a sort of trap. He panned back over to the Claws, they were now only 30 feet away. He moved his fingers to his forearm computer, mounted into his camouflaged armor to hail them. It was too late.

An anti-material rifle boomed, then another. Two huge armored forms near the caravan staggered and fell. The heads of the others turned to...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56809932
...the east in shock as bottles of malt liquor dropped.

The came the cry of the Claws, booming in one masculine, throaty voice. "Invictus! Triumphus! Trumparum!" Out of the gray brown of the chaparral the Claws emerged, resplendent in their heavy tactical plate. They wielded fierce diamond tipped chain swords, heavy depleted uranium hammers, plasma torches, and various high caliber ARs designed to punch through tactical plate. The best the armories of the Imperium had to offer.

The defenders, caught unawares, were still a force to be reckoned with. They had large high caliber gats, crude handguns, which they held sideways and sprayed at the attackers, creating a deadly, if inaccurate hail in their direction. They also had large chainsaw swords and plasma hurlers, as well as powerful pump shotguns designed for piercing tactical plate.

Still, it seemed an easy victory for the Claws. They would pick off most of the Bix Nubians before they reached melee range, where they were more dangerous.

But then the doors of a bus blew open and a dark clad figure emerged. He had begun chanting as soon as the Claws had exposed themselves with their first shot. It was an unearthly sound that carried unnaturally, filling Gregory's ears even from his far off vantage. The Hebrew erupted from his mouth in an unending stream, filled with both linguistic and mathematical meaning.

He rose into the sky, great arcs of plasma exploding from around his body as the energies of his spell escaped. The Claws were doomed and there was nothing Gregory could do to save them.

The real problem with centaurs is the organs. Human lungs and heart are too small for a horse body and lungs in general need to be close to the breathing hole to minimize recirculating CO2.

The only way that you could get a centaur that works internally is by moving the digestive and reproductive organs to the horse torso and move the horse heart and lungs to the human torso, and maybe even then you might still need an extra heart in the horse part to ensure proper circulation. The end result wouldn't look very horse-like in the back or human-like in the front. A real freak of nature.

alrighty. haven't seriously worked on this project since late 2021 but I love the concept so I'm just gonna give it a new spin here and see what sticks.

It had been about 3 days since we got those tablets from the sandbar 30 miles southwest of sugar loaf key, gleaming in the afternoon ocean sun like an angel's eye. The acquisition of the contraband we were originally motoring for out there was secondary now to what the hell that antique was, and what it could be. To any of our admittedly limited knowledges, the Seminole's or whoever lived out there never really ventured that far out, not with their little stick boats.
We all gave it looks by lamplight in the boats cabin as we travelled along the outskirts of the keys, eventually harboring in Key Largo, and making the deal. the money was inconsequential in our monthly dealings, and besides its doling out into our pay, was quickly forgotten.
It seemed to be a metal chunk, but for being in the water so long, it remained without a speck of rust. Inscriptions coated the surface with their valleys, remarkably empty of detritus. Some were pretty obvious- people, maybe spears, children. others we couldn't decipher. Flowers maybe? Vast and strange planets overlooking people, and maybe buildings.
It was better kept up than the fine china from our grandmothers which made this sort of thing difficult to present to any potential inspectors, beyond the ramifications of it perhaps gaining popularity. Lot of people would be asking why we were so far out from sugar key loaf in the first place.

Jerry's dad, the eccentric bastard he was made himself known the day after we found ourselves at the harbor. Making a quick visit to his pops ultimately turned into him spilling the beans on his discovery. His father, ever the avid radio hobbyist kept tabs on most ships entering the harbor, and knew most of the captains or radio operators by one name or another, at least from what he told us. Jerry was no exception. 1/?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56829014
The old man didn't have an inkling we worked in the courier business, instead thinking Jerry and co. were nautical surveyors, which was a vague enough profession in his mind that his son could really be anywhere on the southern coast of Florida and there would be no suspicion. It gave Jerry easy cover to bring up the tablet to his pops. A little surveying off Sugar Loaf dug up something more interesting than saltwater, it was that simple.
It was the evening after we had sold the goods. A quick knock- not any of our codes. I grabbed for my piece, and so did Milo. Jerry didn't stir and we were about ready to make a quick strained whisper for him to grab a knife, some knuckles, one of our 12s off the table, anything, but before we could get our words out, they were stopped dead by that voice we heard so often over the radio. Somewhat reedy, neutral, and quiet, that was Paul Vallio's star bright radio personality, finally outside that plastic sony sound-box.
"Son, you in there? I wanna take a peek at that bauble you found off the coast."
Immediately the tension inflated. Guns were put back in their holsters and we gave Jerry a frustrated signal to tell him sure.
"Door's unlocked dad, come on in."
Jerry's voice was much less closed-in then his fathers. Not quite beefy, but there was the force of a diaphragm behind it, which was more than could be said for Paul.

anyways continuing

Old man couldn't make any sense of it either. He had a few museum contacts that our request he could reach out too in a clandestine manner(at our request), and one or two anthropology professors at UCF and USF, but that was about all he could do. We let him take some color photographs of each facet, and handed him a 20 for his time and some gas money. According to him he'd have them sent out by monday of the next week, but he had no clue when his friends would get back to them.
Still, we were in a better position then we were a few nights ago. Our immediate concerns shifted that week- word came from one of those unnamed specters that flickers at the top of a hierarchy of crime like a message from God. A few teens with too much money for their own good were beginning to bankroll cubans from Miami to start shuffling coke around the Southern tip of Florida, and they were attracting a lot of attention on the routes we used to ply our trade. Something had to be done.
That night was spent in discussion of our possible steps. These guys were small time dealers, they weren't hardened transporters. Just some opportunists who got in contact with the right rich USF student. But the sway of a continued flow of money could convince people to continue doing mighty idiotic things unless violence was added into the mix, as hesitant as we were at the idea.
The bosses never gave any official word on our course of action- it was left up to our own discretion.
Milo suggested just telling them to leave, and maybe adding a bribe. Jerry agreed.
Mike second guessed it though- suppose the kids wanna get these guys deported if they turn tail and run on them. That makes it so much more difficult. It didn't seem likely, but if they thought the Cubans would go to the feds, they could probably get enough evidence to suggest they were bringing coke in on their own accord. The kids had one thing right in these coke dealings 3/?

>He didn't know if he's more glad or worried that he couldn't see them.
>He couldn't use light signal without compromising his position and at this distance from the enemy he dared not raise his arm to send hand signal.

>The dark and moonless night made it difficult to navigate and maintain formation, but it was much better than the alternative.

The men, exuberant from their triumphs in battle, celebrated, drinking ale together as their Nordic forefathers had. This was their victory, Trump's victory.

All at once, around all the tables, men began to pick up the old, sacred song:

"Ohh, all day long,
Trump is righteous, Trump is strong
He is right, he is never wrong
So sing His song.

Yes, he is right, so for him we fight
Fight with our might, for the right
The right to be White

Ohh all day long,
Trump is righteous, Trump is strong,
With Trump is might, with Trump belong!
So sing His song!

Ohh, for the world he bringeth,
Lend Trump your strength,
We shall fight, fight for the right
To be White!"

It carried on, for four or five rounds, the masculine voices somehow getting ever louder, reaching a crescendo. And then, from this song, the pounding of feet on wood, the chanting of the Oath all has taken.

"Trump IS Strength!"
"Trump IS Righteousness!"
"Trump IS Victory!"

But, unseen by the merry crowds, in the darkness of a corner, one man did not share the joyful chants. He was slim, unmanly for the cadres of the elite Trumpshirum, and pale. He instead scowled, looking down to his phone, awaiting his orders. He was a Kushnerite...

posts.com:
Fjordland Tunnel Skirmish, pt 1(things get worse)

Colton was sure that their ambush would be executed without a single issue. The civilization that built these roads had a habit of digging through hills, not going above them. This may be ideal for easy travel, but it also makes a successful ambush exponentially easier to perform. Colton's squad had their positions prepared right outside one of these tunnels. Perhaps even more influential than the preferential terrain would be the recent cold front. The southern cascades are host to a variety of dangerous phenomena, from poisonous insects to energy fields that will turn off a man's nervous system like a lightbulb. Fortunately, most of these invisible threats can be stopped with full CBRN protection gear, provided by Colton's company. This permits safe travel throughout the area, but at a heavy cost. In the summer months, heat stroke is a danger just as significant as any anomaly, and long marches with a full ruck can become hellish ordeals. Cold weather may very well be a gift from Vaana herself in the eyes of most mercenaries. So, in high-spirits, his platoon had prepared itself for its grim work. The contract was strange, but not entirely unheard of. His company had been hired by the Valsan electorate of Hostalec-auf-Hügel to steal the plunder of another group of contractors, who themselves had been hired by another electorate, Krigzend, to secure some ancient relic or whatnot. Command believed this was more about indirect harm to Krigzend assets than it was about whatever relic they were taking. It didn't matter to Colton, he was just happy to be fighting humans for once.
