posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56845720
He was assigned to an MG team, having helped the gunner, a Cairer named Seamus, prepare his position. Their foxhole was by no means an impressive fighting position, but it was deep enough to offer significant protection from any incoming fire, and well concealed between the trees that flanked th3 ancient concrete road. With the other gun teams in position, there was nothing else to do but wait. Only about half an hour had passed until we received a force assessment from scouts on the other side of the tunnel. 4 personnel carriers, old surplus from the 50s, and a civilian truck. One of the PCs had a low pressure howitzer, but besides that, previous information from the company's employer was entirely accurate. The ATGM team announced that their targeting system was, for once, not malfunctioning. Everything was perfectly in place.

A few minutes after the reports, he could hear the engines of the convoy as it reached the end of the tunnel. Colton readied his rifle as the first personnel carrier made its way out of the tunnel, waiting for the ATGM to fire, which would signal the beginning of the ambush. The lead vehicle was some old Novetian model, an 8 wheeled metal box with sloped armor good enough to resist small arms-fire. Instead of the usual machine-gun, it's turret housed a nasty looking howitzer, certain to make short work of their positions. It didn't get the chance to fire. A guided missile flew right through the top armor of the vehicle, detonating an ammo rack and sending the turret flying onto the pavement. Not even a second after, our other positions opened fire on the convoy. A storm of small arms-fire, accompanied by rocket propelled grenades and mortar shells struck the convoy in-sync.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56846040
The PC in the rear was struck directly by mortar fire. It seemed as if the remaining vehicles would try to make a break for it, but they stopped as suddenly as the fighting started. A string of garbled Novetian over his radio and a white flare fired from the civilian truck signaled the surrender of the convoy. Their ambush had been so successful that the enemy had not managed to fire a single shot.

Orders from the sergeant, a veteran of the Waldfurt conflict, were for the riflemen to advance and disarm the surrendering hostiles. Most complied without incident, and any issues were resolved by a firm strike with the butt of a rifle. The PCs were secured and the captured soldiers were put into restraints. There was little ill-will between the companies, so the typical contractor's etiquette would be practiced. It was common among groups who engaged each other for purely contractual reasons to release captured prisoners, and sometimes equipment, after leaving the site of the engagement. Due to the unpredictable nature of mercenary work, accepting such customs was wise. Word gets around quickly, and if a company is known to deny the mercy of another, then they will not receive it.

And that's part 1. I didn't really proofread it but this only ocurred to me after the first post so I figured I might as well post the rest.

Fankasia; prebriefed dateline. Flightplan 9827, W03

Wire took a last look outside the cockpit before again raising his night vision goggles and beginning a scan with his PNVS. Unlike that of the pilot, the CP/G PNVS was simply the TADS slaved to the CP/G's IHADDS. Scanning the horizon, Wire played around with the gain and brightness of the thermal sensors, searching out optimal settings from the system, that he may best seek out anything worth shooting. Ogres, communes of Frogmen, Dragon's nests, etcetera.

Wire set his acquisition source to TADSand went about calling up a playlist of Brocas Helm, played into his helmet. Lizard trimmed the Apache nearly nose to tail, set altitude and attitude hold at 550 feet and likewise, called up a soft playlist of Bert Kaempfert compositions to play while he scanned the surface.
"Contact, unknown heat source, 45 degrees right. Lizard, keep me unmasked." Wire declared as he returned to the TEDAC and noted a white splotch amongst the rocks at the foot of a mesa some 9,000 meters distant.
From reflex, Wire Tapped the "STORE" button on The TEDAC before setting the TADS to the narrowest field of view setting.

While Wire scrutinized the heat signature, and made the decision to ask Lizard to close the distance by about 5,000 meters, Lizard set his right MFD to TV mode and set the video source to the TADS as Kaempfert's rendition of "Blue moon" a song popularized by Frank Sinatra, underscored the whole act in his head.

Wire asked for the closure, and lizard provided , coming to a sagacious out of ground effect hover to observe what creatures might be there to the tune of "Happy Trumpeter."
Wire narrowed his field of view and adjusted gain and contrast, but still sat dumbfounded as he observed that there was one perfectly humanoid figure among the signatures, and about eight figures whose scale was about five sixths of that.
"Elves?"

>>56846684
"....With a human? In private? Out here?" came the reply through wire's ambience of "Cry of the Banshee."
"Lizard, with that scale, there's no way it's elves and an Ogre, or Orks." Wire commented. "Could it be one of those Blood Elves you hear Rumors about and a buncha goblins?" Lizard asked. "Even Blood elves look more gaunt than a human. That's gotta be a human in there. Close to 2,500 Meters." "On it."
Lizard gently bowed the cyclic down slightly and set the helicopter about accruing a slight forward velocity and again began to let out the collective in order to modulate it and stave off an accumulating climb rate.

Slowly, the helicopter accelerated to 45 miles per hour and then the cyclic was pulled back, and the collective further let out until the cyclic was ambled fore and collective was brought in once again to maintain a hover. Wire, having switched to C-HMD acquisition to have a look around for anything that may be around before slaving the TADS to the markpoint and unslaving it to resume observation.

"That's definitely a human with elves." Lizard observed "I owe you a beer when we get home." Wire thought about the facts of the situation and decided that there was no further recourse for it than to report the sighting as an unusual event back at gate 25 and leave it at that.
SUDDENLY, Wire watched in horror as the ARM button changed colors, illuminating the orange A R M light on the upper half of the button. The M230 turned GREEN on the weapons page on his left MFD.
The helicopter began a smooth but still rapid rotation as Wire had realized Lizard WAS'd the gun and set the arm, watching the MANRNG box value change to 1000 as the flattest statement of what should be frantic exclamation sounded to him "Contact left."
The gun followed the PNVS and Wire set a wide field of view to follow the dot on the azumith index just in time to see the ork catapult with a flickering hot stone loaded splinter and shatter as the round count in IHADDS fell.

posts.name: Crashmaster
posts.com:
>>56846998
290
280
270
260
The displayed round count fell as the orks around scattered and strings of high explosive 30mm rounds struck the area around the catapult, setting its sundering fragments to a chaotic dance reminiscent of a time over twenty years prior, when an 18 minute fireworks display detonated in about 20 seconds.

Orks running from such a short distance, in the span of only a couple seconds were dismembered and in two cases hit directly, eviscerating them and sending their tumbling and superheated bodies to the dirt beneath their feet.

As though he'd just witnessed Lizard shoot lightning out of his eyes, Wire felt his poise to fire again in the fervor of the moment and anticipated the shuddering of the airframe, and watched for another five seconds intent on the screen to see nothing came. When Wire looked, he noted that the gun was again, swiveling.
"Good eyes, Lizard." "Wire, think those guys are still there?"
"Lets check." Lizard again rotated the helicopter around and Wire slaved the TADS back to the mark point to see the group at the fire. From his posture he estimated that the elves had been mildly frightened by the noises in the distance, however, the human....
"Lizard, he's waving."
"We're gonna save these tapes for sure.... Lets get out of here."
With that, Lizard switched the right MFD to the TSD page, hit the RTE button, DIR, Point, and entered W04 on the keyboard, and remembered then to activate the aux tank pumps when he read the fuel quantity to be 2,400 pounds.
"I think we're gonna be winchester before we're at waypoint 6. Hope you're still hot on the missiles."
"Yup, I intend to shoot all 8."
"I'm getting tired of jaz, I'm transfering control to you."
"Roger, Wire has control."

posts.name: Crashmaster
posts.com:
>>56847289
Before too long the apache reached waypoint 4 and things looked surprisingly quiet. For a few mintues. Within 10 minutes of their arrival, they'd picked up an as of yet dormant but warm dragon's nest, which for the sake of lightening the helicopter for landing, merited a trivial shot with a hellfire missile, scattering warm humors about an area that must've been 30 yards without leaving a single piece of dirt uncovered.

Five minutes later they found themselves shooting at some form of Giants fast enough that Wire was launching missiles before he even hit the one he was lasing. Finally, after WASing the gun and emptying the remaining 260 rounds, dismembering and disemboweling them with some effort, claiming 19 more kills in total before Lizard began expending the rockets into an ogre breeding pit, wherein Lizard and Wire decided to forget kill counts and make for home.

Finally, after two and a half hours of flight, the apache hovered to a crawl and Lizard took up the effort of hovering to a stop, touching with only a couple miles per hour of velocity left as the helicopter cushioned itself on touchdown, and Lizard let off the collective to ground the helicopter in place, and set the parking brake.
The APU was started and the throttles were cut to idle so the helicopter would remain powered and the engines could cool down. Wire and Lizard went about their post flight checks, setting any adjustable systems where they should be prior to startup, saved their footage, and then proceeded to turn off all lights, cut engines and let the rotor come to a full stop, assisting the last with the rotor brake, and then releasing the brake to preserve hydraulic accumulator pressure, turned off the APU, climbed out, and stretched before debriefs.

"Think they'll like our kills?" Lizard asked.
"Yeah, but we're gonna have to talk a lot about that dude at the campfire."
"It's a likely story. We'll have to tell them the nothing we know-...."
"Something come up?"
"Just..."

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56860579
>1. What are good boots?
describe the environment you're larping in and I'll give you some recommendations


>2. What are good shooting/ballistic eyewear options?
Basically whatever you want that works for you and your ear pro. I just wear my prescription sunglasses because they're already scratched and I got that sweet stiggy in both eyes.

I'll make the point that you should absolutely try on and wear any eye pro for several hours before shooting with them (so you dont fuck them up and can't return them, but ymmv). A lot of eye pro, in my eyes at least, cause a fish eye effect. If you wear only ear plugs, the temples don't matter. If you wear earphones, then you'll need to figure out if you want to switch the cups on your ear pro with ones that have a channel for your eye pro's temples, or if you want to instead seek out eye pro with really flat temples. I'd argue it's smarter to replace your ear pro's cups to gel cups with a channel for eye pro.

Eye pro is something you should neither spend top nor bottom dollar for- cheap eye pro is shit and expensive eye pro is just going to be that much more expensive to replace once you inevitably scratch them.

Idk about bass pro but cabelas usually has a big section for eye pro in their stores so you aren't buying online judging solely by how tacticool they look

I'm going to assume you're not joking or trolling.
AR500's most popular steel plates weigh nearly 10 pounds -- this is more than even the cheapest ceramic Level IV. Those same steel plates:
- Will not reliably stop M193 from a >16" barrel, which is the most common rifle threat in America. Also will not stop any AP threats. Lastly, will not reliably stop .270 Winchester, .300 WM, or other fast-moving hunting calibers. Even the most mediocre Level IV plate will stop all of that.
- Can send bullet fragments flying into your armpits, neck, groin, or jaw. This is almost guaranteed if the shot hits not far from the plate edge.
- Are frequently sold without a spall coating, which makes them downright dangerous.
- Aren't much cheaper than budget ceramic plates. It's $179 for a 10x12" 'A1' plate with the 'build-up' coating. You can get a 10x12" ceramic plate from Blackbeard that will perform much better, at half the fucking weight, and is also multi-curved, for only a few bucks more.
So they're heavy as fuck, they offer shitty protection, they don't catch bullet fragments, and they're really not that cheap. Wearing AR500 is literally worse than wearing no armor at all, and buying AR500 is retarded.

>>56853933
What I did was take an A4 sheet, fold them in half neatly, crease the fold, use a ruler to tear it in half and you essentially get two A5 sheets. Fold them in half, scrape glue across the surface evenly and take care to make sure no air bubbles are trapped. The small size leads to less bending and I'd use heavy books to pin them anyway. Repeat this while watching TV or youtube or whatever. You'll end up with a reasonable stack to work with. At this point you can use white glue to increase thickness, or superglue if you're feeling hardcore.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56854169
Perhaps try using less glue because it seems the paper is being soaked through and thus takes too long to dry.
Alternatively:
- leave it drying in the open air for a minute, you should see it curl, flip it around to cause it to curl the opposite way and then after a minute put it under a weight
- before they start bending too much, glue them back to back so that the curling is neutralized
I admit that this requires experimentation and finesse to get your process down. Too much or too little glue have to be worked out as possible points of failure. I had an old gym membership card that is made of the same material as credit cards and it worked perfectly as a spreader.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Dodecashotgun anon, back after half a year of absence. I've decided to more or less scrap the entire 3D printed fire control group and switch to the idea of electronic ignition for conventional centerfire cartridges. It is annoyingly cumbersome trying to hand fit a homemade system to function reliably 12 times over and I'm getting frustrated with not getting every barrel firing consistently every time.
I did a basic shit test with a bench supply and a primed case in my garage this afternoon. I just set the supply to 30V/10A, held ground on the case head and touched positive to the primer. The supply obviously current limited and reported ~7.5W power output. The primer detonated after approximately 2 seconds, or 15J dissipated energy. The primer actually blew out the back and damaged my alligator clip (pic related). I believe that the primer detonated from heating to its flash point. If energy is applied more quickly, a smaller area may heat up hotter without conducting heat to the rest of the case head, requiring less total energy.
ICs designed to charge photoflash capacitors to ~325V from a battery are widely available and inexpensive. At 325V, I would need a 300uF capacitor to store 15J of energy. This ends up being a realistic number; >300uF capacitors rated for >400V are widely available and relatively cheap. I'm going to see if I can dig up anything at work to test this further, or put in a digikey order if I can't.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56853904

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56854322
Yes, if you send electricity through something fast enough it will heat up more, and the smaller the thing you are trying to send it through, the more it will heat up.
Its directly related to the resistance of the material and the cross section area vs how much electricity you are trying to shove in.

This be something where you made your own primers, with an engineered strip of metal going through that would flare up and burn from your engineered current.

Alternatively, another potential design would be to create a deliberate plasma arc to ignite a primer, though I have no idea what the power requirements and speed for that is.

You can definitely make regular bullets work with electric ignition, but it will be a slower firing semiautomatic deal without a LOT of power.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56855543
I understand what you are trying to say. In my mind, I had intended to accomplish this by having a sharper "firing pin" that makes electrical contact with the primer for the reason you described. At ~325V, an arc would form across a tenth of a millimeter gap, which is too small for me to expect to do deliberately. Some sort of mechanism to strike a spark like a welder is way more that I would want to take on.
What I was describing in my post was that I suspected that the 2s that it took for the primer to detonate with my 10A power supply was long enough for thermal conduction from the primer to the rest of the case head to have an effect. Doing some back of the napkin math, I think my guess was wrong. A shotgun primer weights ~0.250g. The specific heat of copper is 0.385 J/gC. If all ~15J was dissipated evenly in the primer itself, it would have raised in temperature by ~155C. The auto ignition temperature of primers is ~170-190C. The shells were at room temperature ~18C initially. This all adds up to the thermal conduction being negligible.
I'm looking into this specifically for a single shot breech loader, so charge time and battery life are not major concerns for me. A charge time of ~5 sec for a 300uF capacitor with a standard photoflash capacitor charger IC is completely acceptable to me. Better efficiency is desirable in order to have physically smaller capacitors, though.

If you think about it, the machine is ~1500lbs, spindle after gearing and reality is probably about .9 hp. You have to recognize and be able to work around those limitations.
I do production work on the side including large (for the tormach) machine parts and robot feed trays. It's not as productive as a real machine, but people exaggerate the inaccuracy. With correct machining strategy, mainly light radial passes and some massaging I easily hold .001 on bores and height features.
I'm also a professional cutting tool engineer, so I give critics some slack. Not nearly as forgiving as a machine with 25-30hp.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56854322
Think that basing it off a stun gun would work better. The primer would have to me 3 parts though. A core, a middle and an outer layer. The core is metal, and has a pin sticking out into the cartridge, the middle is an isolating dividier and the out metal with another pin. Electricity is run through the inner to the outer and an arch is born. Might have to have the inside facing part of the primer be covered in something isolating as well except for the tips of the pins.
On the bolt you mirror the core, mid and outer. But in the middle you have a tiny button that gets compressed by the cartridge when the bolt lies against the cartridge so that the current can be turned on in the right position to avoid a short.
If you make the bolt out of a slightly heaver material you might be able to hollow out part of the back to fit the actual stun gun parts. Then there's how to hook it to the trigger properly but i don't know about that yet but shouldn't be impossible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56859015
>AR armorers wrench
good, but I find that I only really use the castle nut wrench after I moved to a freefloating handguard that has its own barrel nut wrench. Standalone tools are much easier to use
>Vise
good, make sure it's big enough and that's its secured properly, if you don't have one get a nice workbench too
>Punch set (w hard and soft punches)
Also consider roll pin punches and make sure to have a good plastic/rubber mallet and a roll of masking tape to protect anything nearby from getting marred.
Also related, get a center punch for staking castle nuts. You don't really have to buy a tool for staking the bolt carrier group since that should be done at the factory but you can if you want.
>Vibratite/VC/compound
Sounds good but every thread on an AR-15 that needs to stay is either torqued down tightly, torqued lightly enough that blue/purple loctite can handle it, or is staked outright
Optional, but get it if you want
>Glock sight tool
Sure
>basic cleaning kit/supplies
>bore snake
You don't need to get a full kit, just get the bore snake and buy whatever brushes/patches for the calibers you'll be shooting.
Speaking of cleaning, obtain a giant pile of cleaning rags. A rag to wipe oil and dirt onto is fucking useful and you'll be using it a lot. I have a giant pile of old socks with holes in them. Not great but it works.
>CLP
Cheaper options out there but sure.
>AR upper reaction rod
>AR buffer/receiver clamp (for holding buffer tube in place)
>lower receiver clamp
You could probably replace all this with a bev block, it holds both the lower and upper and it even engages with the locking lugs just like the reaction rod. You'll also get a ton of practice disassembling and putting the bolt carrier group back together which is also useful.
>Torque gauge/driver
Make sure it's calibrated. Also make sure to have a 1/2in breaker bar for going the other way.
>headspace go/nogo gauge
I'll defer to the more experienced but that sounds like a good idea.

It was safer (explosivity) and easier than the fulminate-based primers that preceded it, and it was safer (toxicity) and easier than the lead styphnate primers that replaced it -- we'd probably still be using it except for the whole corrosive salts thing.

Each component is safe individually, it becomes explosive after you mix it (wet) and let it dry. As with any priming compound, you want to use pure ingredients, and work carefully in small batches, but as these things go it's quite well-behaved.

Note that I have no experience with this sort of chemistry, I'm speaking from book knowledge, so please do your own research and don't blow yourself up.

>>56863435
On both a Glock and an AR, a Giggle Switch is compatible with an 80%, yes. You have to change the way you prepare and machine the AR platform to make it work. Polymer-80 ARs lack the "meat" to really take the modification safely: the FCG pins tend to egg out very quickly and can crack the walls of the receiver within a few hundred rounds of even semi-auto fire.
>>56871200
It's moderately poisonous and glass powder is NASTY shit, but you can otherwise safely mix the compound with acetone and work it wet with nonferrous tools on glass with no real worries. The acetone gets it into a thin, well-dissolved paste that's easily manipulate with a small brass spoon. or a brush. It helps that none of the sumbcomponents need to be in absolutely critical percentages *(my test cartridges still ignited with no additional hangfires or FTI when off by ~5%) and (unlike fulminates) you can safely make a few drams to load an evening's cases on the spot without having to brew, prep, and store several pounds of reeeeeeal twitchy primary high explosive in your shed. I do find the Primeall kits tend to make pretty soft primers, but shellac 'em in there and they'll hold up. Their Berdan and Boxer adapter kits are fucking nice for shooting old-school milsurps.
The problem is the potassium salts will deposit in the barrel and hunt every crack and crevice. You have to soak them out with hot water immediately after firing, flush the gun, then dry and oil it and repeat the wash a few days later,, or they will abruptly rot out your bore the instant the humidity creeps above 40%. It seems to be worse with "dirty" smokeless like 22s than the clean stuff.

>>56870745
If your gun is made for quick cycling (bolt right next to trigger, can be cycled without losing sight picture see SMLE) or has to mount a traditional (non-scout) scope, then bent. If not straight is vastly superior. A straight handle facilitates secure and fast cycling using the palm of your hand. It is also better to use brute force on if the bolt is stuck (Mosin-users can relate). Also a straight handle is bigger and therefore better for use with thick gloves, stiff hands, wounded hands, your forearm etc. which all might happen in combat.

posts.name: Anonymous

Previous >>56768631
Nothing new from shotshow edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56846756
Yes, NVD tubes require ambient light to amplify, when you are in an environment with no light such as underground with no ambient light entering the environment at all then NVD tubes will not give you any actual signal it'll be all noise.
As for thermal fusion setup, thermal require different temperature gradient and if the environment is practically the same temp all around you'll also see nothing significant i.e. noise again.
Just use white light at that point.

Don't forget budget thermals. People have had some good results buying AGM or Infiray thermal monos in the $400-600 range and rigging them to head mounts. Remember that thermals are entirely passive with no active IR emissions.

>>56852382
If there's any truth to the myth...and that is an IF...it's likely radiation from thorium in the eyepiece. Thorium was stupidly used in some old lenses and even a few old eyepieces for cameras/optical devices. You do NOT want to spend any serious time with thorium near your eye.

There is a Geiger counter app for iPhones that works, probably for Android as well. You put black tape over the camera lens and it reads the CMOS sensor noise for signs of radiation. It takes a relatively long time for a calibration/reading, but it works. I have one old thorium lens in my vintage camera collection that I found with my iPhone. So you can verify the safety of an old Soviet nvg without buying a Geiger counter.

posts.name: NightVisionPlus
posts.com:
>>56865488
Articulation is incredibly useful in so many scenarios. What if you need to use your unaided eye? On a non-articulating system you have to stow your goggles all the way up. Which comes to one of the biggest drawbacks to any non-articulating system that uses the dovetail mount interface. When the goggles are stowed they stick very far off your helmet and it throws off your center of balance. It will cause neck strain after any extended period of time. Ask any Sentinel, RNVG, or RPNVG user to show their side profile when their goggles are stowed and it becomes readily apparent. This is less of an issue if your non-articulating system is either very lightweight or uses the ball detent mounting system that was specifically designed for the non translating ANVIS goggles.

>>56865623
It's controversial because you are looking at the eyepieces in a position that is off-axis, which could potentially lead to image quality loss. This ends up not being an issue if you're using good glass. Carson PVS-14 eyepieces maintain amazing image quality even off-axis, and I don't notice any image clarity loss even at max pan.

Panning is a compromise between increased wide field of view, at the loss of stereoscopic vision. The further out you pan, the less depth perception you have on the edges of the image. Panning to around 60 - 65° you maintain enough stereoscopic vision in the center that it doesn't become an issue in real world use. Panning is so useful that it is becoming a ubiquitous feature on new binocular systems.

posts.com:
There are zero documented cases of needing to shoot someone in self defense beyond commonly practiced handgun distances while under fire that didn't involve the defender going out of their way to draw fire to themselves (such as yelling at the attacker or standing next to a conspicuously parked police cruiser). With the bullseye pistol technique, you can immediately respond to any scenario well beyond normally practiced handgun distances without needing to spend time you don't have retrieving the LARP rifle you think you need.

Practitioners of the bullseye pistol technique are a force to be reckoned with and can engage targets at 50 yards and beyond with ease without needing an optic. The 5 scoring ring on a 50 yard B-6 bullseye pistol target, which is the lowest scoring ring, is only slightly wider than a popular silhouette targets and a fraction as tall. The 7 ring is only slightly narrower than the -1 or C zone on popular silhouette target and again a fraction as tall. The 8 ring is the size of the common 8" vitals circle and also scales to the width of a popular silhouette target placed at 110-115 yards.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56869522
2003 is boring and makes no sense as we were pivoting our forces to better demolish insurgents in landlocked countries. Now we're pivoting to the Pacific, so I'll spitball like it's 2023 and Congress has decided to give a shit about the Navy.
>railguns in a forward gun turret, 1x2
>DEW-based point defense weaponry
>nuclear reactor (obviously)
>launch, rearming, and control facilities for a number of drones both aerial and naval, primarily on the rear deck
>aerial ECW and spotting drones (unarmed preferably to keep cost down, very light A2A armament if necessary)
>USVs dedicated to carrying various point defense systems (ESSM/SM-3, DEWs if a good enough powerplant can fit in a relatively small craft)
>shitloads of bulkheads
>a distributed C3 system designed around multiple physically separated nodes working in parallel
Overall goal is a vessel that's small (for a BB), fast, shepherds around its own distributed defense network, and can put down sustained hurt from far away for cheap. Maybe closer to a battlecruiser in philosophy than a true battleship, but I like it. Ideally the USVs would also be nuclear-powered, but I doubt autonomously operating nuclear reactors would get the greenlight. I'll settle for a more conventional powerplant, so long as they have
>low staffing requirements
>long maintenance intervals
>(relatively) low observability
>a shitload of defensive armaments
>the ability to be fed targeting data from the BB, the BB's UAVs, and other allied aerial assets
>verification not required

posts.com: We live in a world where everything is designed with human interaction and use in mind. A humanoid shape might not be the best for any specific task, but combat is not a specific task from a technical point of view. Having a humanoid shape is immediately useful because it means being able to pick up any human weapon and fire it. Get in any human vehicle and drive it. Walk through doorways, and up stairs, climb ladders. Being able to broadly do anything a human can do is a pretty important quality in a machine that is supposed to replace a human. Yeah, you can weld a glock to a roomba and it's going to be a hell of a lot smaller, cheaper, and easier to armor, but it doesn't take a genius to see the shortcomings that make it a non viable alternative.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56857493
For that you would require the robot to be in a similar weight class as a human, so let's say under 200kg. That is extremely limiting for any kind of armour or enhancements over a trained and importantly improved human with the same level of technology. Not to mention the price of essentially building an artificial human vs improving and augmenting actual humans.
Lastly you need to consider what is its purpose. For saboutage, infiltration and other similar shenanigans what you described could make sense, though once again we would need to ask why not just use a trained and augmented human instead.
For anything related to direct combat, to be actually effective you have to sacrifice much of those abilities because of weight and complexity. An organized force can set up supply lines and keep lets say a 20mm autocannon fed. Or if we go the other direction and use insect size robots then they have a whole other world of possibilities too.

Because servicing a bunch of different models of weapon and ammo types has always been nothing but good. Interoperability is a huge asset, always overlooked until shit starts breaking. >yeah not for decades at best, a century or two is more likely. there's 0 reason to code a warbot how to drive - if we wanted to do that, we can just write some self driving software and have it done better.
There's plenty of reasons why a machine might need to move a vehicle on a battlefield either because it's too dangerous for a person to do it, because humans have been incapacitated and need to be evac'd, or to commandeer an enemy vehicle. >>56858475
MooseyCreatures specifically has a drop test warning.
TLDR Steyr's drop test is OFF SAFE from a height taller than an NBA player barrel first then butt first - repeated at least 2 iterations with blanks with civilian grade soft primers.
It is practically guaranteed to destroy an AUG stock and it's pretty fucking insane.
Even more so when the Steyr red trigger springs kit conforms to those standards

That said the MC purple, and the Arid are g2g - they aren't replicating the Steyr test, but are slamming the rifle butt and barrel first a la mortaring as well as doing shoulder height drops on dirt/grass.

Corvus is chasing full Steyr drop test compliance, which is why its going to take forever to get them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56861916
Check IWI's website frequently. I stocked up on things like the screws/washers pack, a spare firing pin, ect right when I bought the gun. Any time I buy a gun for a practical purpose, I buy whatever internal extra parts the company offers, to avoid this exact scenario. If my firing pin spring breaks and IWI has been out of business for 20 years, I can replace it.
> I get the feeling it's not critical but I don't like shooting a gun that I know is broken
I would assume it has the same role as most firing pin springs: keeping the firing pin from bouncing into the primer of the next round being fed due to the inertia of the bolt moving forward. It being broken won't prevent the gun from firing, but it might double-fire if your ammo has thin primers, and it makes the gun less drop-safe. I don't think it would cause any other issues. The reverse (tough spring/short pin) happens more often with rifles, which causes light primer strikes, although I haven't heard anything about any tavor having light primer strikes.
> The X95 Tavor is still in production. I don't know why I can't get this part or parts kit.
You know who makes it, right? They used to give free cleaning kits with each rifle too until they realized they could save a penny by selling them separately. Check Apex and other gun parts websites, the guns are popular enough that there must be spare parts out there

In "The Coldest Winter," a guy on Macarthur's staff recounts the moment he lost all faith in MacArthur and knew a disaster was coming.

In one of the rooms they had a big map of the peninsula. At the top was hundreds of red markers for the Chinese. He asked:

>Uh, aren't we worried about all those Chinese forces. Look how many regiments there are, we'll be overrun."

>"Regiments? Oh no, those are divisions. But don't worry, boss says they wouldn't dare do a thing."

Yeah, they missed some due to bad weather, but you can't miss well over a million men, division after division, massed on the border.

And they had no reason to underestimate them, China had been at war since 1915, with a brutal civil war before the Japs came. Then, when the world had peace, the Chinese had 5 more years of war. Even with tons of US WWII surplus the communists won. The deadliest war since WWII is still the continuation of the Chinese Civil War. These weren't fresh conscripts, they were badly outgunned (no air support early on, essentially no armor or artillery, just LMGs, burp guns (shitty Chinese PPSh clones), rifles, and mortars, all man hauled, but they had excellent discipline and morale early on.

The one expression "don't do X or you'll go to Charlie company," comes from a real Charlie company that went from full strength to 3 surviving men, two of whom were captured, in one night. It was an unmitigated disaster.

>MacArthur reportedly told Truman that he was confident of early success in the North Korean offensive, and that he no longer feared Chinese intervention.
>Just 10 days later, the Chinese army, which had been secretly massing at the border, made its first attack on the allies. In the days that followed, the allies' headquarters received intelligence that Chinese forces were hidden in the North Korean mountains, but this was disregarded.
>The Chinese troops withdrew, and the allies interpreted these initial skirmishes as simply defensive. Undeterred, General MacArthur ordered a bold offensive on 24 November to push right up to the Yalu River, which marked the border between North Korea and north-east China.
>He optimistically hoped this would finish the war and allow the troops "home by Christmas". But it was instead to mark yet another turning point in the conflict. The next day, about 180,000 Chinese "volunteers" attacked.
>A shocked MacArthur told Washington: "We face an entirely new war."
>He ordered a long and humiliating retreat - performed in sub-zero temperatures - which took the troops below the 38th parallel by the end of December.
>As Chinese troops unleashed a renewed offensive, the allies were forced to withdraw south of Seoul in January 1951. Here, in the relatively open terrain of South Korea, the UN troops were better able to defend themselves. After a few more months of fighting, the front eventually stabilised in the area of the 38th parallel.

>Hoping to repeat the success of the earlier First Phase Campaign, the PVA 13th Army[nb 3] first launched a series of surprise attacks along the Ch'ongch'on River Valley on the night of November 25, 1950 at the western half of the Second Phase Campaign[nb 4] (Chinese: 第二次战役西线; pinyin: Dì'èrcì Zhànyì Xīxiàn), effectively destroying the Eighth United States Army's right flank while allowing PVA forces to move rapidly into UN rear areas. In the subsequent battles and withdrawals during the period of November 26 to December 2, 1950, although the US Eighth Army managed to avoid being surrounded by PVA forces, the PVA 13th Army were still able to inflict heavy losses onto the retreating UN forces which had lost all cohesion. In the aftermath of the battle, the US Eighth Army's heavy losses forced all UN forces to retreat from North Korea to the 38th Parallel.
>But during the chaotic UN retreats, no reconnaissance was conducted to determine the state of the Chinese forces.[2] As a result, Walker ordered the Eighth Army to abandon North Korea on December 3,[217][220] much to the surprise of the PVA commanders.[221] The following 120 mi (190 km) withdrawal to the 38th Parallel is often referred to as "the longest retreat in US military history."[222][223][224] Aside from extremely low morale after the battle, the entire Eighth Army was also gripped with "bug out fever" during the retreat,[225] and a song called the "Bug-Out Boogie" was composed to commemorate the Eighth Army's defeat.[226] Walker died two days before the Christmas of 1950 when a truck driven by a ROK soldier collided with his jeep, and Lieutenant General Matthew B. Ridgway assumed the command of the US Eighth Army.[227] At the UN, all hopes for a unified Korea were abandoned, and a ceasefire at the 38th Parallel was proposed to China on December 11, 1950.[228]

Motorized forces, even back then, could be 10 times faster than light forces.

But operational mobility is still key, as the retreat of US forces proves : imaginé the casualties if US forces had been strictly on foot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Like, I know the arguments from both sides and the whole debate on whether or not you should have a gun on a plane is something I don't think there's a right answer to. There's just enough pros and cons for it to go either way. Yes, America suffered big time in 'Nam at first when Phantoms didn't have a nose gun and early AIM-7's and AIM-9's were absolute shit, however it's pretty easy to see how missile technology has evolved considerably and engagements are now flinging fire and forget missiles that are guided in by AWACS rather than needing to be guided in with the fighters own radar.

I guess I would be on the "gun not required" side more than the "gun required" one, but I dunno, there's a lot of factors that can cause an actual engagement of a peer to peer enemy to make having guns a necessity. Stealth makes it so you can't just fling missiles from 100km away as you can't detect the planes until you're within 10-20km, and a lot of engagements are going to wind up being on the deck as non-stealth planes use the higher air resistance at sea level to cause missiles to lose a lot of their range. I think in a WW3 scenario where the best of the best is fighting massive, dozen+ jet battles, guns will end up being needed just as much as close-range IR missiles. But fighting goat fuckers or 4th gen stuff, guns are absolutely useless. Maybe the future will be in the ability to remove an INTERNAL gun bay depending on the mission.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm fucking sick of you obvious /pol/ and reddit transplants coming in here and talking about shit you obviously don't know about. To fix that, we're going to have a Read A Fucking Book thread. Specifically field manuals although all non-fiction educational military books are welcome.

NOTES ABOUT FIELD MANUALS
>FMs about mostly the same topics (Infantry platoon, company, battalion) will have a lot of repeated paragraphs. This is normal.
>FMs generally do not include specific techniques for the usage of military equipment, for example a book about armor operations will not include information about how to load and fire an M1A2's gun. Some of that information is classified, other parts of it are only given to soldiers in training for those platforms. This is normal.
>You must ALWAYS reference the era and stated purpose of the field manual. A field manual about infantry tactics from 1955 will not include vital information about current warfare such as the use of portable radios. Older manuals are generally more direct and easier to read, newer manuals are more technical.

>FM 3-0 : Operations
https://armypubs.army.mil/epubs/DR_pubs/DR_a/ARN36290-FM_3-0-000-WEB-2.pdf

This has a basic overview of the US Army's new approach to warfare. A lot of it is recycled from previous doctrine but it is essential to read.

>TC 4-02.1 - First Aid - 2016
https://armypubs.army.mil/epubs/DR_pubs/DR_a/pdf/web/ARN14135_TC%204-02x1%20C2%20INCL%20FINAL%20WEB.pdf

A basic overview of military first aid. A lot of this is at the level of a first aid course, some of it is more vague, any proper first aid training will include practical lessons.

>FM 5-103 : Survivability - 1960s
https://archive.org/details/milmanual-fm-5-103-survivability

Information about entrenching forces to protect them from hostile fire. Some of this is outdated (precision bombing basically did not exist back then) but against direct fire, normal artillery, etc it's useful.

1/2

FM 100-2-1 The Soviet Army: Operations and Tactics
https://irp.fas.org/doddir/army/fm100-2-1.pdf

FM 100-2-2 The Soviet Army: Specialized Warfare and Rear Area Support
https://irp.fas.org/doddir/army/fm100-2-2.pdf

https://www.trngcmd.marines.mil/Portals/207/Docs/MCIS/ITEP/RITC-East/FM%20100-2-3.pdf

All three are dated from 1984 and serve as a detailed overview of how the Soviets conducted ground operations during the Cold War. I own two of three physical copies of these FMs courtesy of my old S2 tossing them out. Sadly they didn’t have 100-2-2 or I could’ve completed the trifecta, but I did snag a USMC FM regarding insurgencies in LatAm during the mid 1980’s. That one went over cell structure, funding and attack methodology though I doubt it’s any different from other Army FMs on COIN. I’ll try to find an online version when I have time.

As for nonfiction I’ve been reading Blank Spots On The Map by Trevor Paglen. Doesn’t really teach you anything brand new about Black Sites but does show how to spot black projects through public means. One of the best chapters focuses on NRO satellites and how they manage to be detected by amateur hobbyists through open source data.

posts.sub: How do I control shaky/wobbly hands while shooting?
posts.com:
Not sure if it is just me or if this is a common issue but I have a hard time keeping my point of aim on the desired point of impact. It is hard to explain but it is not due to flinching when I pull the trigger, I have traced it down to being me wobbling the gun a little bit while trying to hold it still. This happens to me with rifles in unsupported positions and a little bit with handguns, it makes sense that it would happen with a very heavy rifle, but I have very light rifles that the same thing happens to a small but significant degree. Its almost like the rifle is too light to hold still if that makes sense.

What can I do about it? Does anybody else have this problem? I don't think its because I am "weak" or anything, I am tall and built from years of weightlifting and exercise, and its not that the rifle is being pulled down more than it is side to side or the fact that I "over correct" (for lack of a better term) when I find myself off target.

I have ms so my hands are very unsteady. Heavier guns are actually easier to shoot with because the inadvertent shaking doesn't move them as much. It also helps with long guns to really press it hard against your shoulder.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Specifically in rifles, you need to:
lean into the rifle
pull that sucker tight into your shoulder pocket with your right hand
control the rifle with your left hand

At longer ranges and shooting for groups, it will never be perfect unsupported. Learn to take your shots when the crosshairs align with the target without jerking the trigger

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Because you're posting photographs of the Liberia/Sierra Leone conflict, which was somewhat unique in the level of societal collapse it caused.

Basically:
>Liberia was significantly better off than the interior of Africa, which has very limited trade with the outside world.
>Elite of former American slaves made bank off of resources extraction and formed a local elite, while natives were generally oppressed.
>Lots of natural resources wealth and on the coast so plenty of trade going on to get automatic weapons, grenade launchers, etc.
>Huge population boom occurs post colonialism in the region due to rapid advances in basic medical care/sanitation/vaccines/mosquito nets, along with agricultural improvements and food aid.
>Extremely young population, like Mali today, where 50+% are under 14.
>When massive, destabilizing war breaks out, kids are most of the population and warlords begin recruiting kids, having them commit atrocities to build loyalty, and give them drugs.
>Few professional fighters, no military culture, but tons of modern small arms.
>Total lack of training and young kids fighting = retardation
>Shit like General Butt Naked leading kids into battle naked after doing magic rituals

This isn't all of Africa. Some places have experienced fighters and state military. In the interior, it is actually more chaotic, with decades of war, but the society isn't so lopsidedly young and adult men have been doing the fighting for generations and it is less dumb.

The gear is maybe more ridiculous because it is isolated with little trade, so people are using craft made musketoons and swords still, but combat techniques for these primitive weapons are actually coherent.

E.g., these guys have to make their own firearms and ammo from scratch, which is impressive, and have tactics that make sense for their weaponry.

>>56855811
The budget option ?
Tons of local volunteers advancing, spacing them as much as visibility allows, with two lines so chances of missing something is slim.
Keep your actual troops in reserve, ready to be thrown at whatever part of the formation get "lucky" first.

Enemies can push through but then they are on foot, which means you only have to focus your reserve on a small area to catch them and defeat them in details. This is the best scenario, against a numerically inferior enemy both unprepared, overly confident and with a time constraint because of supply or terrain.

If supplies and terrain allow for it, enemies can retreat stealthily as you advance. Provided you got enough volunteers to rotate, you can keep up the search while enemies cannot rest. If you lack the numbers, technology can help, with even commercial drones covering ground faster but that's just eyes, not actual boots on the ground.

If terrain and preparation allow it, enemies can hide and let your volunteers pass them by. That's risky if you got two lines. A well-prepared foe with already-built hideouts might opt for that, though. Your local auxiliaries might lack training and motivation to do a thorough swipe.

The worst option (for you) is if enemies try to circle around your line, either to avoid battle or to ambush and then retreat with less constraint as to where.
The longer and thicker your line is, the harder it is for the enemy to pull that one of... but unless you have unlimited supply of men and time, a correctly informed enemy can plan for a proper escape that way, estimating the upper limits as to how far it can move before your line overrun the available ground.

Technology equipment and training can make this easier but in the end, you someone or something with a gun blocking the path and advancing.

I don't think you'd have to make them, considering that the machine gun bans in the US kept them from being sold. There would have been literal millions of the things if it weren't for that, so a large amount of supply, and not a lot of demand, because these things eat 9mm food. Speaking of Mercedes, that's what Hi Point carbine looks like when you put it next to a Sten. I wouldn't pay more than 200 USD for a Hi Point carbine, yet I'm supposed to pay more for a Sten?
Finally, modern manufacturing is really damn efficient. The bottleneck in Sten production wouldbe welding and the welds are so simple I think you could fix that with a welding robot. Hell, the bolt wouldn't have to be done on a mix of lathes and mills, it'd be done on a single cheapo Haas CNC lathe.
Finally, there would be newer, better submachineguns with more features developed in the meantime, yet those would be more suited to modern manufacturing, so I'd expect something like the proverbial Hi Point Subgun at 250-300 USD new, which would push Sten prices down further.
Granted though, 100 might be a bit of a push, but I was trying to make a point. 250 used seems perfectly feasible, because that's what they're already selling for in Europe.

Hey /k/, I just watched Godzilla vs. SpaceGodzilla, and wanted to share something dumb from it that I'm sure some of you will be interested in.
In the movie, a character named Yuki is trying to hunt Godzilla, and his weapon of choice is a flashpaper .22lr M-110 pistol, that's apparently standing in for a high caliber single shot rifle.
It's meant to fire the 'Yuki special'; a blood coagulant that will poison Godzilla. Yuki determined that Godzilla's weak point is his armpit (based on nothing), and believes that a 'high caliber rifle' shot will penetrate his hide there and the coagulant will kill him.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Here's a second shot of him loading the bullet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's the only part where he actually fires.
Setting aside using a .22lr pistol for a single shot high caliber rifle, you can see he fires two shots in rapid succession anyway.

These are probably the best two Godzilla vs. the (conventional) JSDF scenes of the Heisei era.
The JSDF actually helped Toho with stock footage, advisers and real active duty personnel as extras, until after Godzilla vs. Mothra, because they got pissed they were depicted as accidentally targeting the Mothra larvae after it had ended it's rampage.
Militaries are finicky fuckers like that. The US military refused to help the movie Rampage (the one with The Rock) because the military would've been depicted as 'too weak,' but they also forced a story change in JPIII since one of the endings had the pteranodons attacking marines on the beach and getting murked by A-10s, which they felt depicted the the military as 'bullies' given how one sided it would have been.
